questions.text:
A woman presents with insidious-onset breathlessness and occasional exertional chest pain. Further examination and investigations indicate a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following causes is classified under group 2 of the WHO classification of pulmonary hypertension and its causes?

BMPR2= bone morphogenic protein receptor 2
questions.solution:
Among the given causes, the one that is classified under group 2 of WHO classification of pulmonary hypertension and its causes is left ventricular systolic dysfunction.

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is characterized by an elevation in pulmonary arterial pressures and increased vascular resistance caused by various causes. It is defined by mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) > 20mmHg

Clinical features include dyspnea, edema, chest pain, and syncope. It is irreversible as it does not have a curative treatment and thus can lead to decompensated right heart failure and death. 

Clinical signs may include right heart failure features such as elevated JVP, edema, and ascites as a result of disease progression. Chest auscultation may reveal loud P2, S3, and S4. 

Investigations of PH include: 

  • Echocardiogram with bubble study is an important screening test. It usually shows a dilated, hypertrophied right ventricle and increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
  • Right heart catheterization is the gold standard test to establish the diagnosis of PH and to select appropriate therapy.
  • Chest X-ray - may show obliteration of retrosternal space, enlarged pulmonary arteries, and peripheral vascular pruning
  • ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

questions.text:
In which of the following patients is induction of labor contraindicated?

LSCS = lower segment cesarean section

choices.text: A patient with antepartum hemorrhage due to premature placenta separation
An intrauterine dead fetus retained for more than 2 weeks
Previous history of one LSCS done due to contracted pelvis
Unstable lie after correction into longitudinal lie

questions.solution:
Here, induction of labor is contraindicated in patient with previous history of one lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) due to contracted pelvis.

Here history of one LSCS per se is not a contraindication, but contracted pelvis is a recurrent indication for cesarean section and thus here induction of labor is contraindicated. 

Other options:

Option A: Here patient has abruptio placentae and it is an indication for induction of labor.

Option B: In intrauterine fetal death, we wait for spontaneous expulsion but induction is done when it is infected, causes psychological distress to the mother, or is retained for more than 2 weeks.

Option D: After correction of unstable lie if labor is not induced then it can again get unstable. So, this is a clear indication of induction of labor.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: What is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image above represents the Bragg-peak effect of a proton.

The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. Proton therapy, therefore, allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

Protons and the Bragg peak effect:

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. The proton is very fast when it enters the patient’s body and deposits only a small dose on its way. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak. 

Other options:

Option A: The BOLD (blood oxygen level dependent) effect forms the basis for functional MRI (fMRI).

Option B: The Bohr effect is the loss of affinity for O2 with decreasing pH. It occurs in the microcirculation as oxygen is consumed and CO2 (carbonic acid) is released by tissues.

Option D: The Haldane effect is the phenomenon whereby increasing arterial PO2 reduces the ability of the blood to store CO2 (as Hb-bound, carbamino Hb; or as HCO3-), thereby increasing the CO2 partial pressure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old painter presented with chronic right shoulder pain. The physician performed a belly press test on the patient. Which of the following muscles is he specifically testing for?
questions.solution:
Belly press test is used to assess the subscapularis muscle.

In this test, the patient is asked to place their hand on the abdomen and bring their elbow forward, thus pressing the abdomen. If the subscapularis is torn the patient will not be able to do this, and thus, the elbow will move backward.

Apart from this, the lift-off test is also used to assess subscapularis muscle. In this test, the patient is asked to stand and place the dorsum of the hand against the mid-lumbar spine. The examiner then lifts this hand off the back and asks the patient to hold it right there. Inability to do so points towards the weakness of the subscapularis.

questions.text: A patient suspected to have biliary tract abnormalities undergoes the investigation shown in the image below. Identify the imaging and structure marked as A.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP), and the structure marked as A is the common bile duct.

MRCP is a non-invasive test showing a heavy T2-weighted image. The endoscope or contrast medium is not used as bile itself serves as a contrast medium.

The image given below shows endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: Identify the histological section of an abdominal organ from the image below.
questions.solution:
The histological section shown in the above image is the spleen. 

The spleen is histologically composed of:

  • White pulp - For some distance, each arteriole is surrounded by a dense sheath of lymphocytes. These lymphocytes constitute the white pulp of the spleen.
  • Penicilli - The arteriole then divides into a number of straight vessels that are called penicilli.
  • Ellipsoid - Each of the penicilli shows a localized thickening of its wall that is called an ellipsoid. The ellipsoid consists of concentric lamellae formed by the aggregation of fibroblasts and macrophages.
  • Ampulla - Distal to the ellipsoid, the vessel dilates to form an ampulla, the walls of which become continuous with the reticular framework.
  • Red pulp - As a result, blood flows into spaces lined by reticular cells, coming into direct contact with lymphocytes there. The part of splenic tissue, which is infiltrated with blood in this way is called the red pulp.
  • Sinusoids - Blood from spaces of the red pulp is collected by wide sinusoids that drain into veins in the trabeculae.

The splenic artery after entering the hilum of the spleen divides into about five branches that enter the organ independently. Each branch divides and subdivides as it travels through the trabecular network. Arterioles arising from this network leave the trabeculae to pass into the inter-trabecular spaces.

Stave cells: The sinusoids of the spleen are lined by a somewhat modified endothelium. The endothelial cells here are elongated and shaped like bananas. They are referred to as stave cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labor, has obstructed labor. Her uterus undergoes tonic contraction and retraction forming a ring. Which would best describe this ring?

choices.text: Chances of uterine rupture are less
It is not felt per abdominally

questions.solution:
Bandl's ring/Pathological retraction ring is formed in cases of obstructed labor. The statement that best describes it is that it moves progressively upwards.

In obstructed labor, the upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigorously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction, while the lower segment dilates. With each contraction, there is myometrial shortening so that the upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter, while the passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner. The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

The thinned-out lower segment can ultimately give away and lead to uterine rupture. Thus chances of rupture is more. It can be felt abdominally but cannot be felt vaginally. Polarity is normal.

Other options correspond to constriction ring/Schroeder's ring.

Constriction ring/Schroeder's ring is formed due to incoordinate uterine contraction (abnormal polarity) when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM). The upper segment contracts and retracts with relaxation and the lower segment remains thick and loose.

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring

Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.

questions.text: A middle-aged HIV-positive woman presented with altered sensorium and neck rigidity. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed capsulated budding yeast cells on India ink preparation. The culture on bird seed agar showed black colonies. What is the likely route of infection of the organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. The route of infection of Cryptococcus is by inhalation of spores.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. It may cause infection in immune-competent people, resulting in a flu-like illness with complete recovery.

Infection in immunocompromised people like AIDS patients or patients with hematological malignancies results in meningoencephalitis.

questions.text: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is usually associated with polyps in which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is usually associated with polyps in the small intestine.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The pigmentation is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, and perianal and genital regions. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years.

Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11 are present in half the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histologic examination shows a characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

A complication of Peutz-Jeghers polyps is intussusception, which is occasionally fatal. Peutz-Jegher syndrome is associated with a markedly increased risk of colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Note:- Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen in FAP, not Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text:
You are working in World Health Organization (WHO). Recently, a new virus named SARS-COV2 (SARS-CORONA Virus 2) broke in the city of Wuhan in China, and the WHO declared it to be an emergency on 31 December 2019. You are posted as the chief investigating officer for investigating this epidemic turning pandemic. Given below are five different statements on the steps involved in the investigation of an epidemic. Arrange them in sequential order.
  1. Obtain the map of the Wuhan region and get a detailed population analysis.
  2. Verify the outbreak of an epidemic.
  3. Retrieve epidemiological case sheets to search all cases.
  4. Data analysis based on time, place, and person.
  5. Evaluate the ecological risk factors.
questions.solution:
The correct order of sequence involved in the investigation of an epidemic includes 2-1-3-4-5.

Investigation of an Epidemic: 

A) Steps

  • Verification of diagnosis
  • Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic
    • Defining the population at risk obtaining a map of the area
    • Counting the population
  • Rapid search for all the cases
    • Medical survey
    • Epidemiological case sheets
    • Searching for more cases
  • Data analysis based on time, place, and person
  • Formulation of hypothesis
  • Testing of hypothesis
  • Evaluation of ecological factors
  • Further investigation of the population at risk
  • Writing the report

B) Final Epidemic Report

  • Background including geography, climate, demography, socio-economic groups, health service organization, surveillance data, and normal disease prevalence
  • Historical data including previous occurrences of the epidemic, the occurrence of any related diseases, and discovery of the primary case in the present outbreak
  • Methodology of investigations including case definition, epidemiological questionnaires, collection and laboratory techniques
  • Analysis of data including clinical and epidemiological data, modes of transmission, laboratory data, and all their interpretations
  • Control measures including strategy definitions, methodology of implementation, evaluation methods, and preventive measures

The final report on an epidemic after investigation must include data like previous occurrences of the epidemic, the discovery of the first case of the current epidemic, the questionnaire used in the epidemiology of the epidemic, and lab techniques used among others

questions.text: A nulliparous female with a history of infertility presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and sudden onset of acute abdominal pain. Her serum hCG is 2500 IU. A diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Since the patient has ruptured ectopic pregnancy it should be managed immediately by surgery and the most appropriate management is salpingectomy.

In salpingectomy, the fallopian tube which has ruptured is removed from its uterine attachment with bipolar cautery. It can be done for both ruptured and unruptured ectopic pregnancy. But linear salpingostomy can be done only in case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy. Here the products of conceptus are removed through a small incision on the antimesenteric border of the fallopian tube and it is left unsutured.

Management of unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy includes expectant, medical, and surgical management options.

Expectant management - an observation with serum β-HCG monitoring.

Indications:

  • Initial serum hCG level < 1,500 IU/L and the subsequent levels are falling.
  • Gestation sac size less than 4 cm.
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS 
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS
  • Hemodynamically stable

Medical management - systemic use or direct local use of chemotherapeutic drugs

  • Drugs used: Methotrexate (MTX 50 mg/m^2 single dose intramuscularly), potassium chloride, prostaglandin, hyperosmolar glucose, actinomycin.
  • Regular monitoring of serum β-HCG.

Indications:

  • The patient is hemodynamically stable
  • Serum hCG level less than 5,000 IU/L
  • Tubal diameter less than 4 cm without any fetal cardiac activity
  • Absence of any intra-abdominal hemorrhage

Surgical management - laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy, microsurgical laparotomy 

Indications:

  • Cases that don't fit the medical therapy criteria
  • Serum β-HCG levels are elevated despite medical therapy
  • Persistence of fetal cardiac activity

Estimation of serum β-HCG should be done weekly till the value becomes less than 5.0 mlU/mL, following conservative surgery or medical treatment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with dry, scaly dermatitis. On evaluation, he had a deficiency of essential fatty acids. The human body cannot synthesize essential fatty acids because of the inability to introduce a double bond beyond which carbon atom from the carboxy terminal?
questions.solution:
Essential fatty acids cannot be synthesized in the body, because of the inability to introduce a double bond beyond the 9th carbon atom from the carboxyl terminal. Hence, it should be supplied through a proper diet.

Essential fatty acids are polyunsaturated fatty acids required for biological processes but are not synthesized by the body.

The two essential fatty acids in humans are as follows:

  • Alpha-linolenic acid (omega 3 fatty acids) - It has 18 carbon atoms and 3 double bonds at positions 9, 12, and 15. The last double bond is at the 3rd position from the methyl terminal, so it is also called omega-3 fatty acids. It is the precursor of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA).
  • Linoleic acid (omega 6 fatty acids) - It has 18 carbon atoms and 2 double bonds at positions 9 and 12. The last double bond is at the 6th position from the methyl terminal so it is also called omega-6 fatty acids. It is the precursor of arachidonic acid.

Sunflower oil and corn oil are rich sources of linoleic acid. Fish oils contain alpha-linolenic acid.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed a Stanford type B aortic dissection. Which part of the aorta is involved in this condition?
  1. Ascending aorta
  2. Arch of aorta
  3. Descending aorta
questions.solution:
The part of the aorta involved in the above clinical scenario, i.e. Stanford type B aortic dissection, is the descending aorta.

Aortic dissection most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients.

It is initiated by an intimal tear, which allows blood to penetrate into the medial layer, producing a cleavage plane (false lumen) between the inner two-thirds and outer one-third of the media. The true lumen is separated from the false lumen by an intimomedial flap.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, which is based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system, which is based only on the location of the proximal tear. 

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending aorta and arch of aorta Type II Type A

Descending the aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

Clinically, patients present with tearing chest/back pain associated with diaphoresis, syncope, weakness, and dyspnea or neurological manifestations.

On examination, unequal pulses or blood pressure in the extremities may be seen due to changes of flow in the true and false lumens. There can be hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, findings of aortic regurgitation, and pulmonary edema. 

Imaging: 

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

In hemodynamically stable patients, the diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double lumen aorta. 

The image below shows aortic dissection in the thoracic aorta with the true lumen, as well as the false lumen. The true lumen is often the smaller of the two because of being compressed by the false lumen.

questions.text: A biochemist wanted to study the difference in gene expression between a cancer cell and a normal cell. He used the following method shown in the image. Identify the method.
questions.solution:
The method shown in the image is called microarray analysis. 

It can be used to study mutations in DNA and variations in gene expression.

It consists of a slide with tiny spots of DNA called a DNA (or gene) chip. For studying gene expression, mRNA is taken from the sample and then its complementary DNA (cDNA) is made. This cDNA from the normal cell is labeled with green fluorescence, and the cDNA from the cancer cell is labeled with red fluorescence. Then, both are allowed to hybridize with the DNA on the chip.

Interpretation:

  • Black spots represent no expression by both normal and cancer cells.
  • Red spots represent more expression by the cancer cells.
  • Green spots represent more expression by normal cells.
  • Yellow spots represent equal expression by both cells.

Using the microarray technique, the differing patterns of gene expression between two types of cells can be analyzed.

Option B - A northern blot only measures mRNA production from one gene at a time.
Option C - Southern blot can only analyze DNA not the products of DNA expression.
Option d - Western blot measures protein production.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with severe joint pains for 1 month. She also says her skin feels firm and tight for the past 6 months and progressed rapidly since then. Further history taking reveals features of mild Raynaud's syndrome since 6 months. On examination, the skin over the fingers, legs, arms, and trunk appear firm and indurated on palpation. Which of the following antibodies will most likely be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of severe arthralgia and diffuse involvement of the skin with rapid progression, along with a recent history of Raynaud's phenomenon, is suggestive of diffuse systemic sclerosis. Anti–topoisomerase I antibody is most likely to be elevated in this patient.

Reasons why this cannot be limited systemic sclerosis:

  • The onset of Raynaud's syndrome coincides with the onset of skin symptoms, whereas in limited systemic sclerosis, it precedes skin symptoms and has a history of over a decade.
  • Here Raynaud's is less severe, whereas in limited systemic sclerosis it is more severe.
  • Here, the skin involvement is diffuse, including the trunk, and showed rapid progression, which are features of diffuse systemic sclerosis.

Systemic sclerosis is a chronic and progressive disease that involves sclerosis of the skin and the organs. It can be divided into limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) and diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSC) depending on the extent of skin involvement.

In lcSSc, the skin involvement has a slow progression and is limited to fingers, distal to elbows, face. This disease has a slow progression. On the contrary, in dcSSc, the skin involvement is early and rapid. It can involve fingers, extremities, face, and trunk. They also have severe joint pains and musculoskeletal involvement.

Other options:

Options A and C- Anti-double-stranded DNA antibody and anti-Smith antibody are seen systemic lupus erythematosus. The patients might have a rash over the malar eminences or circular lesions with slightly raised, scaly hyperpigmented erythematous rims. They might also have swelling and tenderness in their hands, wrists, and knees.

Option D- Anti-centromere antibody is seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Here, the skin involvement is seen distal to the elbow, in the extremities, and distal to the elbows.

questions.text: A child presented with croup and undergoes a radiological examination. The radiograph revealed the steeple sign. Identify the radiographic view that reveals this sign and the structure that forms the narrow tapering shape seen in this sign.
questions.solution:
The steeple sign is seen in acute laryngotracheobronchitis or croup. A chest X-ray in the PA view reveals this sign and the structure that forms the narrow tapering shape seen in this sign is the subglottis, because of edema of this region.

Laryngotracheobronchitis is caused by the parainfluenza virus, usually of types 1 and 2. It leads to edema of the subglottic larynx, which produces stridor and respiratory distress.

questions.text: Among the given women, the best candidate for the role of accredited social health activist (ASHA) is a 25–45-year-old woman who is ______.

choices.text: Unmarried with education up to the 10th standard
Married with education up to the 5th standard
Unmarried with education up to the 5th standard
A widow with education up to the 10th standard

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D, woman who is a widow with education up to the 10th standard.

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with a formal education of at least up to 8th grade. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years (married/divorced/widow) and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population, but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Roles of ASHA:

  • To create awareness and provide information to the community on determinants of health such as nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices
  • To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breast-feeding and complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception
  • To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract infection/sexually transmitted infection 
  • To mobilize the community and help them in accessing health and health-related services.
  • To arrange and escort pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility
  • To inform sub-center/primary health center about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/disease outbreaks in the community
  • To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign

 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text:
Which of the following are electron microscopic findings of reversible cell injury?
  1. Nuclear changes like pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis
  2. Appearance of small amorphous densities in mitochondria
  3. Plasma membrane alterations, such as blebbing and loss of microvilli
questions.solution:
The appearance of small amorphous densities in mitochondria and plasma membrane alterations, such as blebbing and loss of microvilli are electron microscopy findings of reversible cell injury. 

Nuclear changes like pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis are seen in irreversible cell injury. 

Features of reversible cell injury:

  • Cellular swelling - earliest change
    • ATP depletion leads to sodium-potassium pump failure
    • Na and water accumulate within the cell causing cellular swelling
  • Fatty change -
    • Seen in cells involved in or dependent on fat metabolism (liver hepatocytes and myocardial cells)
  • Light microscopy - no noticeable changes
  • Ultrastructural findings on electron microscopy -
    • Mitochondrial swelling and small amorphous densities
    • Plasma membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
    • Swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
    • Detachment of ribosomes from granular ER
    • Nuclear changes like disaggregation of granular and fibrillar filaments

questions.text: A woman presenting with burning pain after the meal was prescribed medicines. It did not improve and she was investigated with upper GI endoscopy. An ulcer was found located on the lesser curvature of the stomach. Which of the following cannot be a type of this ulcer, according to modified Johnson's anatomical classification?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Type III. Type III occurs in the prepyloric region (not in the lesser curvature).

Type I - Lesser curvature at incisura

Type IV - High on the lesser curvature

Type V - Anywhere in the stomach (So lesser curvature can be involved here also)

Helicobacter pylori and NSAID use are the most important factors in the development of peptic ulcer disease. The most common sites for peptic ulcers are the first part of the duodenum and the lesser curvature of the stomach. NSAID-induced ulcers can occur anywhere in the stomach. 

Type Location Acid level
I The lesser curve at incisura Low to normal
II Gastric body with duodenal ulcer Increased
III prepyloric Increased
IV High on the lesser curve Normal

questions.text: You had started warfarin for the management of venous thrombosis in a patient. Your senior consultant advises adding heparin for the initial 5 days. The need for add-on heparin despite warfarin therapy is primarily due to:

choices.text: Shorter half life of factor IX
Longer half life of factor II
Longer half life of factor VII
Shorter half life of factor X

questions.solution:
Among the given options, factor II shows the longest half-life of about 50 hours, as a result of which the full antithrombotic effect of warfarin is not achieved for several days. For this reason, until the full effect of warfarin is achieved, it must be overlapped with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant, such as heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux.

At therapeutic doses, warfarin decreases the functional amount of each vitamin K–dependent coagulation factor made by the liver by 30–70%. But it has no effect on the activity of factors that are already in circulation, and these must be cleared before it can produce an anticoagulant effect.

Factor VII activity declines most rapidly when warfarin is administered. It has the shortest plasma half-life among the vitamin K–dependent clotting factors.

questions.text: A 36-year-old P2L2 woman visits the OPD requesting sterilization surgery.  Of the many methods available, the doctor suggests the procedure described in the image given below. Identify this method of tubal sterilization.
questions.solution:
The method of tubal sterilization shown in the image is the Uchida technique.

In this method, the serosa over the mid segment of the fallopian tube is stripped off exposing the muscular layer. The exposed part is ligated and excised. The proximal end is buried in the broad ligament and the distal end is left open outside the mesosalpinx. An advantage of this method is that the minimal excision of the tube provides scope for tuboplasty in the future.

An image showing the Uchida technique is given below.


Option A - Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium and the distal stump is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

The procedure described in the image below is the Irving procedure.


Option B - Pomeroy procedure is the most popular technique of tubal sterilization. In this method, the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised as shown in the image below.


Option D - Madlener procedure is a simple procedure but is associated with high rates of failure. In this procedure, the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision. A loop is made, and is crushed and ligated with a nonabsorbable suture as shown below.


Other methods of sterilization:

  • Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:
    • Kroener's technique: It refers to the excision of fimbriae (fimbriectomy). 
    • Aldridge method: A hole is made in the anterior leaf of the broad ligament and the fimbrial end is buried into this.
    • Cornual resection: The cornual part of the tube is resected where it is attached to uterus.
  • Laparoscopic techniques:
    • Using Falope ring, Hulka clip, and Filshie clip.
  • Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, which is confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text: A patient with COVID-19 infection is being ventilated using the following device. What is the maximum flow rate that can be delivered using this device?
questions.solution:
The image given above is a Hudson face mask. The maximum flow rate that can be delivered using this is 10 L/min.

The Hudson mask is also known as a simple face mask. It is a low-flow, variable performance device. They provide an oxygen flow rate of up to 5–10 L/min and provide a variable FiO2. The body of the mask functions as a reservoir for both oxygen and expired carbon dioxide. It is used in patients who require oxygen therapy for shorter periods of time.

The illustration given below shows a Hudson face mask.

Venturi mask is a high-flow, fixed-performance oxygen delivery system. The highest oxygen concentration (FiO2) delivered is 60% at a flow rate of 15 L/min. It works on the Bernoulli Principle, which states that in order to maintain a constant flow, a fluid must increase its velocity as it flows through a constriction.

It is used in patients who require greater FiO2 such as COPD patients, where it is important to provide controlled oxygenation. It is available in different colors, with the green valve venturi mask providing 60% FiO2. 

The illustration given below shows the Venturi mask.

The non-rebreather mask is used to deliver oxygen at higher concentrations (FiO2: 80–95%). It uses a reservoir bag to let the oxygen get concentrated while a one-way valve doesn't allow it to breathe in expired air. It can deliver flow rates of 10–15 L/min. Thus, maximum flow rate is 15 L/min.

It is used in patients with significant hypoxia, with relatively normal ventilation, such as victims of trauma or carbon monoxide exposure.

The image given below shows a non-rebreather mask.

Nasal cannulas are low-flow, variable performance devices, with a flow rate of 1-4 L/min. It is used in patients who require low supplemental oxygen. The nasopharynx acts as the reservoir in such cannulas.

The illustration given below shows a nasal cannula.

questions.text: A researcher is using a systematic interactive forecasting method that is used to obtain a consensus forecast, i.e. to determine the degree of agreement on a topic. This method uses questionnaires that are answered by experts in two or more rounds. Identify the method.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B-Delphi method.

Delphi method: It is a systematic interactive forecasting method that is used to obtain a consensus forecast, i.e. to determine the degree of agreement on a topic. This method uses questionnaires that are answered by experts in two or more rounds.

Other options:

Option A: The method of communication used for counseling, wherein a person is helped to make a decision about health is known as the "gather approach", e.g. contraceptive counseling. GATHER stands for:

  • G- Greet
  • A- Ask
  • T- Tell options or give answers
  • H- Help in making choices
  • E- Explain everything about the decision
  • R- Return for follow-up

Option C: A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Option D: In a panel discussion, 4 to 8 experts are allowed to have a discussion on a topic in front of an audience.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 28 weeks of gestation undergoes a 75-g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Her fasting plasma glucose level was 100 mg/dL, 1-hour OGTT is 190 mg/dL, and 2-hour OGTT is 160 mg/dL. Which of the following statements is true about her condition?

choices.text: Her condition causes the highest rates of anomalies in the fetus.
There is increased risk of fetal macrosomia.
Oral hypoglycemic agents are the first-line agents for treatment.

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), and there is an increased risk of fetal macrosomia in gestational diabetes mellitus. Maternal hyperglycemia causes fetal hyperinsulinemia, which leads to increased fetal growth or macrosomia.

All pregnant women are screened at 24–28 weeks for GDM. In India, we follow the one-step method recommended by The International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG).

Threshold values for gestational diabetes (75-g OGTT):

Plasma glucose Glucose concentration threshold
Fasting 92 mg/dL
1 hr OGTT 180 mg/dL
2 hr OGTT 153 mg/dL

One or more of these values in a 75-g OGTT should be equaled or exceeded to make a diagnosis of gestational diabetes. In this case, all three values exceed the threshold, so a diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus is made.

Option A: Women with overt diabetes are at a greater risk of developing congenital defects than those with gestational diabetes. Women with overt diabetics are those who are known to have diabetes before pregnancy.

Patients with overt diabetes show superoxide-free radicle production and hyperglycemia-induced gene upregulation since the first trimester. The first trimester is when organogenesis takes place. Hence, overt diabetes patients have a higher risk of developing congenital anomalies. GDM develops during the late second to early third trimester and does not affect organogenesis. 

The following are the laboratory findings that would be suggestive of overt diabetes in a mother:

  • Fasting blood sugar of at least 126 mg/dL
  • A random blood sugar of at least 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c of at least 6.5%

The anomalies seen in an infant of a diabetic mother are cardiac anomalies (most common), neural tube defects, cleft palate, hypospadias, renal problems, etc.

Caudal regression syndrome is the most characteristic anomaly seen in overt diabetes.

Option C: Hyperinsulinemia can cause neonatal hypoglycemia.

Option D: Insulin is the preferred first-line agent in women with gestational diabetes, when target glucose levels cannot be achieved through nutrition and exercise.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) of the left kidney is admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and management. A contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows the presence of growth in the left kidney. Which is the surest finding that you will use to label the tumor as stage 4 RCC?

choices.text: Involvement of wall of vena cava

questions.solution:
Extent beyond Gerota's fascia is the surest finding to label the tumor as stage 4 RCC.

The staging of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is based on size, position, and lymph node involvement. The stages and the features of each stage are given below.

Stage of RCC Features 
Stage I Tumor <7 cm in the largest dimension, limited to the kidney
Stage II Tumor >7 cm in the largest dimension, limited to the kidney
Stage III Tumor in the major veins, or invading the wall of vena cava with intact Gerota’s fascia, or regional lymph nodes involved
Stage IV Tumor beyond Gerota's fascia

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) arises from the epithelium of the proximal convoluted tubule and is frequently detected coincidentally. It has a male preponderance.

There are six major subtypes which are clear-cell, papillary, chromophobe, MiT family translocation, collecting duct, and medullary type.

The classic triad of loin pain, loin mass, and haematuria is seen in <10% of patients with renal tumors. Rather, the majority of diagnoses result from incidental findings during procedures like CT imaging, performed for other reasons.

Major risk factors for RCC include age, sex, obesity, hypertension, and cigarette smoking. Other medical conditions associated with RCC include chronic kidney disease, hemodialysis, kidney transplantation, and acquired cystic disease of the kidney (ACDK).

Genetic factors also contribute to an increased risk of RCC, evidenced by individuals with a family history of renal cancer having an approximately two-fold increased risk. The most common symptoms associated with paraneoplastic syndromes are hypercalcemia, fever, and erythrocytosis.

Surgeries done for RCC:

  • Partial nephrectomy, the goal of which is to completely remove the primary tumor while preserving the largest possible amount of healthy renal parenchyma. It is used for renal tumors <7cm in size.
  • Classic radical nephrectomy involves the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes.

There also exist targeted therapies for RCC, which include tyrosine kinase inhibitors like sorafenib, sunitinib, and lenvatinib; anti-VEGF monoclonal antibodies like bevacizumab; and mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and temsirolimus. The average duration of disease control with these agents is 8–9 months.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheezing, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed a bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following finding marked by an arrow. What are these structures made of?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals, lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma. The structures marked by the yellow arrow in the image are Charcot–Leyden crystals and these are made of an eosinophilic-derived protein called galectin 10.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic-derived protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.text: A psychiatry resident asks the patient a certain set of questions using the questionnaire given below. What is he trying to assess?
questions.solution:
The given score is MMSE (Mini Mental Status Examination), which assesses cognitive dysfunction as in dementia. 

MMSE is a 30-point questionnaire from categories including orientation, attention, memory, construction, and language, which tallies up to a score of 30. It is easy to administer and takes less than ten minutes to complete. A score of less than 23 points to cognitive impairment. It was devised by Folstein.

Components:

  • Orientation
  • Registration
  • Attention and calculation
  • Recall
  • Language

It can be used to screen for and assess dementia. Some other screening tools are the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA), the tablet-based cognitive assessment tool, and the cognistat.

The picture below shows a sample of the MMSE form:

Advantages:

  • Ease of administration and scoring
  • Less time consuming
  • Can be reliably administered and scored by trained clinic staff
  • Can be tolerated even by very low-functioning patients.

Disadvantages:

  • Influenced by the education level of the patient, i.e. highly educated patients with mild Alzheimer's disease may perform very well on the MMSE, whereas healthy individuals with low education may earn scores in the “impaired” range.
  • May not identify mild cognitive defects or deficits associated with noncortical dementias.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was diagnosed with malaria. His body temperature measured 39°C. Which curve in the graph below and its description depict the compensatory mechanism adapted by his body at this phase?

choices.text: Red curve-Increased evaporative heat loss by shivering
Red curve-Increased heat production by shivering
Blue curve-Increased heat production by sweating
Blue curve-Increased evaporative heat loss by sweating

questions.solution:
The correct answer is blue curve-increased evaporative heat loss by sweating. 

The graph here depicts the effect of hypothalamic temperature control centers on changing core body temperature below or above the critical level of 37.1°C (98.8°F).

The blue curve depicts a sharp increase in the rate of evaporative heat loss, resulting from sweating when core body temperature rises above 37.1°C. As in the given clinical scenario, the body temperature is 39oC , the compensatory mechanism is by sweating resulting in heat loss and thereby reducing the body temperature to the normal core temperature(critical temperature).

The red curve depicts a sharp increase in heat production from shivering when core body temperature falls below 37.1°C. Even though option B is correct factually, it is not the compensatory mechanism expected in the given clinical scenario.

questions.text: The autopsy of a middle-aged woman with tuberculosis reveals the following finding in the lung. Identify the pathophysiology of this lesion.

choices.text: IFN-gamma produced by Th2 cells resulting in non-caseating granuloma
IFN-gamma produced by Th1 cells resulting in caseating granuloma
IL-1 produced by Th2 cells, resulting in non-caseating granuloma
IL-1 produced by Th1 cells, resulting in caseating granuloma

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of tuberculosis and the image showing a cheesy appearance of necrosis due to incomplete proteolytic digestion of the necrotic tissue are suggestive of caseating granuloma. The pathophysiology is IFN-gamma produced by Th1 cells activates macrophages and results in the caseating granuloma. 

Note - In parasitic infections, such as schistosomiasis, the granulomas are associated with strong Th2  cell response and eosinophils.

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production

Anti-inflammatory cytokines:

questions.text: A study was conducted to compare the incidence of post-partum depression in the mother as compared to the sex of the child. For assessment, Edinburgh Depression Scale Score (EDSS) was used. The study was divided into mothers with male baby as one group to be compared with mothers with female baby. Which of the following statistical test will be used to determine the association?
questions.solution:
Chi-square test is used to compare qualitative data and compares 2 groups with independent measures. Hence it is the appropriate test here.

Option A: Student’s t-test is for quantitative data. Here the data is qualitative, hence it can't be used.

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post- intervention data of the same group. This does not apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

The variables used here is yes/no signifying presence/absence of postpartum depression. If the values obtained were compared, then unpaired t test could be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient came to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset of severe pain in the right side of the lips, gums, and cheek. It occurs during both day and night, lasts for 2-3 minutes, and has been present for 3 weeks. Which of the following is not an adverse effect of the first-line agent used for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms are suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. Carbamazepine is the primary agent for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. Hypernatremia is not an adverse effect of this drug. 

One of the late complications of therapy with carbamazepine is the retention of water, with decreased osmolality and concentration of sodium in plasma.

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition seen more commonly in women over 50 years. This condition is characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain, most commonly involving the second and/or third divisions of the trigeminal nerve territory. Pain is repetitive, severe, and very brief.

This occurs spontaneously or is triggered by touch, a cold wind, or eating. Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux). No objective signs of sensory loss.

The first-line agent used in the treatment is carbamazepine. If carbamazepine is ineffective, then second-line agents like lamotrigine and phenytoin are used. 

Side effects of carbamazepine therapy include:

  • Drowsiness
  • Vertigo
  • Ataxia
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Diplopia, blurred vision
  • Hematological toxicity( aplastic anemia, agranulocytosis)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions (dangerous skin reactions, eosinophilia, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly)
  • Hyponatremia due to water retention

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is a known case of colon cancer. He develops puffiness around the eyes, pitting edema of the lower limbs, and ascites. His 24-hour urinary protein level was 4 gm/24 h. CT abdomen shows renal vein thrombus. What is the most probable cause behind this nephrotic presentation?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on nephrotic presentation and history of colon cancer associated with thrombotic complication points to membranous glomerulonephritis also known as membranous nephropathy.

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in older adults, with a peak incidence in 30–50 years and a male: female ratio of 2:1. It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease. It can be primary (75% of cases) or secondary. Factors that can lead to secondary membranous nephropathy include:

  • Solid malignancies - colon, breast, lung.
  • Infection - Hepatitis B, Syphilis, Malaria, Schistosomiasis
  • Rheumatological disorders - Lupus, IgG4-related disease.

Light microscopy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall, due to deposition of immune complexes between the basement membrane and the overlying epithelial cells. Irregular spikes of basement membrane between these deposits are best seen with silver stains. Immunofluorescence microscopy shows diffuse granular deposits containing IgG and C3. Electron microscopy shows electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes.

This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome complicated with renal vein thrombosis. Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants such as antithrombin III in the urine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old fisherman was brought dead. His family accuses his friend of murdering the fisherman by pushing him into the river when he was alive and claim that drowning has resulted in his death. Which finding of the autopsy will refute the family's accusation?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option A-hydrostatic lung, which is a postmortem finding. When a dead body is thrown into the water, water passes into the lungs due to hydrostatic pressure. The rest of the 3 options describe antemortem findings in a case of drowning, which is described in a question.  

Other options:

Option B: Edema aquosum - This occurs when the victim is alive but unconscious at the time of the drowning. This is mere flooding of the lungs with the water without the formation of froth as respiratory efforts are absent.

Option C: Emphysema aquosum - This is seen in cases when the victim is alive and conscious. Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. It is one of the most valuable positive signs of drowning. The edema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death. Hence, the lungs are held in the inspiratory position. The impression of the ribs on this overinflated lung leaves visible and palpable grooves on the lateral surface. 

Option D: Paltauf’s spots - These are subpleural hemorrhages that reflect hemolysis within intra-alveolar hemorrhages, which occur due to the rupture of alveolar walls due to increased pressure by forced expiration suggestive of antemortem drowning.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - the most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But, the absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).
  • Emphysema aquosum - overinflation of the lungs
  • Paltauf’s spots - subpleural hemorrhages that reflect hemolysis within intra-alveolar hemorrhages
  • Dilation of the right heart and great veins - subjective and non-specific finding
  • Foreign material in the stomach - watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed, or sand
  • Hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - a positive non-specific sign of drowning
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses - not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning

Note: The autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. The most useful one is froth in the air passages.

questions.text: The given image shows the appearance of the oral cavity on examination of a patient with suspected leukemia. Which of the following is the induction regimen used for this type of leukemia?
questions.solution:
The given image shows swollen and spongy gums, indicating gum infiltration. This is a characteristic feature of acute monocytic leukemia (AML-M5). The induction regimen for this type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is cytarabine + daunorubicin.

Infiltration of the gingivae is characteristic of the monocytic subtypes and also with 11q23 chromosomal abnormalities. Thus, less commonly, infiltration is also seen in acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AML-M4). But in this type also the induction regimen remains the same.

Treatment of AML :

It is divided into two phases

  1. Induction
  2. Postremission management (consolidation)

In the induction phase, the goal is to achieve complete remission. For all the types other than acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL)/(AML-M3), the regimen consists of cytarabine administered as a continuous intravenous infusion for 7 days and daunorubicin or idarubicin administered intravenously on days 1, 2, and 3. This is known as the 7 + 3 regimen.

Other drugs include CD33-targeting immunoconjugate gemtuzumab ozogamicin.

Once complete remission is achieved, the patient is consolidated with either chemotherapy only or with transplanation depending on various factors.

For AML-M3, the treatment differs in that it uses All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA). ATRA induces the differentiation of leukemic cells having the t(15;17), which have disruption of the RARA gene. Low-risk patients are treated with a combination of ATRA and arsenic trioxide (ATO).

Cladribine only is used for hairy cell leukemia. The combination with daunorubicin is not used.

questions.text: A mother presents with itching that worsens at night. On examination, you notice lesions as shown in the image below. Her 15-day-old baby has some vesicles on various parts of his body. Considering your diagnosis based on these observations, which is the site where the lesions will be found in the baby but not in the mother?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of itching in the mother that worsens at night, with similar symptoms seen in her baby, and physical examination revealing burrows is suggestive of scabies. In scabies, the site that is involved in neonates but not in adults is the face.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic skin infection that is transmitted through the means of close personal contact/fomites. It is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis or human itch mite. It leads to severe pruritus, excoriating papules, and burrows. The typical lesions of scabies are burrows. The pruritus typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared. Typical sites involved include the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, and genitalia.

The image below shows an adult S. scabiei mite.

Treatment for scabies:

  • Administration of antihistamines for pruritus
  • Application of topical 5% permethrin and rinsing off after 8–12 hours, with reapplication after 1 week, if required
  • Washing of clothes and linen and anti-scabetic treatment of family members

questions.text: A patient presents with joint pains which are severe when he wakes up in the morning and decreases with activity. His hands are shown in the image given below. He has papulosquamous lesions on his skin which have a silvery scale. What is the most efficacious treatment for his joint pains?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the above picture is psoriatic arthritis. Nail changes are obvious and inflammation of the DIP joints can be observed. The most efficacious treatment for his joint pains is methotrexate.

Psoriasis is a papulosquamous disease with joint and nail manifestations apart from the skin. It has silvery scales. The joint manifestations in psoriasis are referred to as psoriatic arthritis. It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy and hence it is associated with HLA-B27. It is seen in 5-30% of patients with cutaneous manifestations. Nail involvement increases the risk of concomitant joint involvement. The x-ray shows a 'pencil in cup' deformity due to tapering of phalanges with cupping of proximal parts. All the bones of a single digit may be involved, referred to as ray deformity.

CASPAR Criteria is used to diagnose Psoriatic Arthritis. The patient must have the inflammatory articular disease (joint, spine, or entheseal involvement) with ≥3 points from any of the following five categories: 

  • Evidence of current psoriasis, a personal history of psoriasis, or a family history of psoriasis
  • Typical psoriatic nail dystrophy observed on current physical examination
  • A negative test result for rheumatoid factor
  • Either current dactylitis or a history of dactylitis recorded by a rheumatologist 
  • Radiographic evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation in the hand or foot

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with a high fever with noisy breathing, cough, and cold for the past few days. An X-ray of the neck revealed a retropharyngeal abscess. The space beneath which layer shown in the given illustration is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D-11. The layer labeled as '11' in the given image is the buccopharyngeal fascia. In a retropharyngeal abscess, the pus collects between the buccopharyngeal fascia and the prevertebral fascia. 

An acute retropharyngeal abscess commonly occurs in children below 3 years of age due to infections of adenoids or tonsils that cause suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes and lead to abscess formation. Since the retropharyngeal lymph nodes disappear after this age, an adult retropharyngeal abscess is uncommon and usually occurs secondary to trauma.

The clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor, croupy cough, torticollis (extended stiff neck), and unilateral swelling on the midline of the posterior pharyngeal wall.

The lateral view of the radiograph shows a soft tissue swelling and the widening of the prevertebral shadow. The extent of the abscess can be visualized on a contrast-enhanced CT scan.

Treatment is usually done by incision and drainage of the abscess and antibiotics. Tracheostomy is required in cases of large abscess that cause obstruction to the airway or lead to laryngeal edema. 

Other options:

In the image

  • 3 - Superior constrictor muscle
  • 10 - Pharyngobasilar fascia

questions.text: An alcoholic patient was brought to the emergency room by his relatives in a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness. His spot blood glucose level was found to be 45 mg/dL. Which of the following is responsible for this low blood glucose level?

choices.text: Decreased diversion of acetyl CoA to ketogenesis

questions.solution:
This patient has ethanol intoxication, and increased lactate/pyruvate ratio is the reason for his low blood glucose levels.

The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by dehydrogenases is accompanied by the reduction of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) to NADH. This will result in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. 

Due to this, the following metabolic reactions that require NAD+ are inhibited:

  1. Glycolysis
  2. Citric acid cycle (ketogenesis favored)
  3. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  4. Fatty acid oxidation

Apart from this, there is an increase in two reactions:

  • Pyruvate to lactate 
  • Oxaloacetate to malate

Both of these reactions lead to a decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis; a reduced level of these substrates leads to a decrease in blood glucose levels, causing symptoms of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness.

A decrease in oxaloacetate can impair the ability of the citric acid cycle to metabolize acetyl-CoA and divert fatty acid oxidation toward ketogenesis.

questions.text:
Match the following columns:
Surgery/wound Expected infection rate 
1. Elective hernia repair a. 1.5%
2. Elective colorectal surgery b. 2.4%
3. Elective cholecystectomy c. 10.2%
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option B-1-a, 2-c, 3-b.

There is no need to remember the actual percentage values. Wounds have to be arranged in increasing order of infection rates. Surgical wounds are classified based on the expected amount of bacterial load at the time of surgery. 

Class I surgical wounds are clean wounds. They are noninfected surgical wounds without any inflammation.

Examples:

  • Hernia repair
  • Breast biopsy specimen

Class II surgical wounds are clean/contaminated wounds. They are surgical wounds that include an entry hollow viscus such as the respiratory tract or gastrointestinal tract under controlled conditions without significant spillage. Examples:

  • Elective cholecystectomy
  • Elective gastrointestinal surgery (not colon) 
  • Elective colorectal surgeries have a higher rate of infection among class-II wounds. 

Class III surgical wounds are contaminated wounds. They include fresh open accidental wounds, surgeries with a major break in sterile technique, gross spillage of the gastrointestinal tract, or incision through an inflamed nonpurulent tissue.

Examples:

  • Open cardiac massage
  • Penetrating abdominal trauma

Class IV surgical wounds are dirty wounds. They are old traumatic wounds with the presence of necrotic tissue and perforated viscus with a heavy load of contamination.

Examples:

  • Perforated diverticulitis
  • Necrotizing soft tissue infection

questions.text: A patient presents with the sudden eruption of the following lesions. What is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Seborrheic keratoses may suddenly appear in large numbers as part of a paraneoplastic syndrome known as the Leser–Trélat sign. The most likely underlying cause is gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma.

The keratoses possibly develop due to the stimulation of keratinocytes by transforming growth factor-α (TGF-α), which is produced by tumor cells, most commonly from carcinomas of the gastrointestinal tract.

The histological image of seborrheic keratosis given below shows benign basaloid cells associated with prominent keratin-filled horn cysts. Variable melanin pigmentation is present within these basaloid cells, accounting for the brown coloration.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man weighing 50 kilograms has a serum sodium level of 110 mEq/L. Calculate the sodium deficit for desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
The sodium deficit in this case is 900 mEq.

It is calculated by

Sodium deficit (mEq) = Total body water (TBW) x (Desired sodium concentration - Current sodium concentration)

Where,

TBW = 0.6 x body weight in kilograms, for males, and

        = 0.5 x body weight in kilograms, for females

Hence, in this case:

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 50 x (140 - 110)

                     = 0.6. x 50 x 30 = 900 mEq

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with symptoms of fever and pharyngitis following his return from a summer camp. On examination, you find signs of acute follicular conjunctivitis with tender and enlarged preauricular lymph nodes. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of pharyngoconjunctival fever. It is caused by adenovirus which is a non-enveloped, space-vehicle-shaped dsDNA virus.

Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute highly infectious illness caused by adenovirus serotypes 3 and 7. It occurs as outbreaks, in schools, summer camps, and prisons.

It presents as fever, pharyngitis, and acute follicular conjunctivitis with tender, enlarged preauricular adenopathy. The illness usually lasts for about 1-2 weeks followed by complete recovery.

Other illnesses caused by adenoviruses include-

  • Respiratory tract - Tonsillitis, pharyngitis, pneumonia.
  • Eyes - Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, acute follicular conjunctivitis.
  • Gastrointestinal tract - Acute viral gastroenteritis.
  • Urinary tract - Acute hemorrhagic cystitis. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. Tissue culture, serodiagnosis, and polymerase chain reaction for detection of viral DNA may be used.

Note: Adenoviruses are being used as gene delivery vehicles for cancer therapy and gene therapy. They are also used in oncolytic therapy aimed at directly killing tumor cells by viral lytic replication.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used in Ilizarov ring fixator.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Kirschner wire (K-wire).

Kirschner wire or K-wire has multiple uses. Insertion is stress-free, associated with less soft tissue damage, and allows for early exercises after removal. The diameter of the K-wire is 1 to 3 mm. The wire is pointed at both ends for both antegrade and retrograde insertion. The shape of the tips could be trocar or diamond or threaded.

Uses of K-wire:

  • To fix fractures in children
  • To give traction e.g. for olecranon fracture
  • To fix small bone fractures
  • In llizarov ring fixator

Other options:

Steinman pin - It is a stout, straight steel rod used to provide skeletal traction. Its diameter ranges from 3 to 6 mm. The common sites where it is used include the upper end of the tibia, supracondylar region of the femur, and the calcaneum. 

Cortical screw: They are threaded throughout the entire length and function as a positional screw or a lag screw for interfragmentary compression.

Cancellous screw - It has larger threads and therefore has more purchase in soft cancellous bones.
