questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with painful menses and pain during intercourse. Per vaginal examination revealed a normal-sized uterus and tenderness in the lateral fornices. A speculum examination revealed bluish puckered spots in the posterior fornix. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?

TVS - Transvaginal sonogram

TAS - Transabdominal sonogram

MRI - Magnetic resonance imaging
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with symptoms of dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea is most likely suffering from endometriosis. The presence of puckered spots in the posterior fornix is pathognomonic of endometriosis. Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis.

Endometriosis is a condition that is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue in ectopic sites such as:

  • Ovary (chocolate cysts- left/right lower quadrant pain)
  • Pouch of Douglas (pain during defecation)
  • Uterosacral ligaments (chronic pelvic pain & infertility)
  • Appendix (right lower quadrant pain)
  • Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis
  • Umbilicus
  • Lung (cyclical hemoptysis)

These extra-uterine sites of endometrial tissue are influenced by cyclical changes in the hormone levels which give rise to location-specific symptoms as mentioned above.

Management:

Investigations include:

  • USG: TVS will show a chocolate cyst.
  • MRI
  • CA-125 more than 35 U/mL
  • Laparoscopy: Gold standard for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. It is used to locate the sites, take a biopsy and surgically remove the deposits.

Drugs used for symptom control include the following:

  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Mirena IUD
  • GnRH analogs
  • Letrozole

Surgical management includes:

Minimally invasive surgery may be used to destroy the tissue by cautery, laser vaporization, and lyse adhesions that have formed as a complication of endometriosis.

Major surgical measures include incision of chocolate cyst and removal of lining, salpingo-oophorectomy, hysterectomy, and unilateral or bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

 

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A middle-aged sedentary male was diagnosed with essential hypertension. While presenting the case history of the patient, a final year MBBS student was asked about the 'Rule of halves' pertaining to hypertension. What does it mean?

choices.text: 50% of the hypertensive patients of general population are aware of having the condition.
50% of the hypertensive patients of general population are treated for the condition.
50% of the hypertensive patients of general population are adequately treated for the condition.
50% of the hypertensive patients of general population are aware of the complications of hypertension.

questions.solution:
The rule of halves pertaining to hypertension means only 50% of the hypertensive patients of the general population are aware of having the condition (option A).

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

Other options-

Option B- 50% of the hypertensive patients of the general population who are diagnosed/aware of the condition are treated for it.

Option C- 50% of hypertensive patients who are under treatment are adequately treated for the condition.

Option D- 50% of the hypertensive patients of the general population are aware of the complications of hypertension is a wrong statement. There is no mention of the complications of hypertension in the rule of halves.

questions.text: What is the effect of sympathetic nervous system on salivary secretion, compared to parasympathetic nervous system?

choices.text: It produces more but thicker saliva.
It produces more but thinner saliva.
It produces less but thicker saliva.

questions.solution:
Both the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems stimulate the release of saliva.

The sympathetic nervous system produces lesser and thicker saliva compared to the parasympathetic. 

Secretion of ions in saliva: Salivary secretion occurs in two stages:

The first stage involves acini, which secrete ptyalin and/or mucin together with some ions. The composition of the ions is similar to that of the extra-cellular fluid.

The second stage involves the ducts. As the primary salivary secretion flows through the ducts, two active transport processes occur:

  • Na+ is actively re-absorbed and K+ is actively secreted, in exchange for Na+.
  • HCO3- is secreted by the ductal epithelium into the lumen of the salivary ducts. Some of this secretion occurs by passive exchange of bicarbonate for Cl-.

As a result, the Na+ and Cl- concentrations are lower than that of plasma, while K+ and HCO3- concentrations are higher than that of plasma.

Composition of ions:

  • Under resting conditions, the concentrations of Na+ and Cl- in saliva are about 15 mEq/L each, which is 1/7th to 1/10th that of the plasma concentrations.
  • K+ concentration is about 30 mEq/L, which is seven times higher than that of plasma.
  • HCO3- concentration is 50 to 70 mEq/L, which is two to three times higher than that of the plasma.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman presents with irregular cycles and an inability to conceive. On examination, she has facial acne and dense black hair on her upper lip. The ultrasound image of her ovaries is given below. Which of the following is not an endocrinal change seen in her?

AMH: Anti-Mullerian hormone
LH: Luteinizing hormone
FSH: Follicle stimulating hormone
SHBG: Steroid hormone binding globulin
questions.solution:
The ultrasound shows multiple cysts in the ovaries, and along with the given clinical symptoms, it suggests a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The endocrinal change not present in PCOS is increased steroid hormone–binding globulin (SHBG) levels.

Insulin is increased in PCOS due to insulin resistance. This increase in insulin suppresses SHBG synthesis. Apart from this, increased levels of androgens, cortisol, progestins, and growth hormone also suppress SHBG.

Other endocrinal changes seen in PCOS are as follows:

  • Increased LH due to altered gonadotrophin-releasing hormone (GnRH) pulsatility
  • Increased LH: FSH ratio (>2:1) due to an increase in LH 
  • Increased androgens such as DHEAS, testosterone, and androstenedione
  • Increased AMH due to an increase in the number of follicles
  • Decreased SHBG due to suppression by insulin
  • Increased insulin

PCOS is characterized by multiple small cysts in the ovaries usually of a diameter of 2–9 mm.

The Rotterdam criteria for the diagnosis of PCOS is the presence of two out of the following three:

  • Oligo and/or anovulation
  • Clinical and/or biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism
  • Polycystic ovaries by ultrasound - ≧12 follicles in either ovary measuring 2-9 mm and/or ovarian volume > 10mL

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A female patient presents with headache and vomiting. On examination, papilledema was noted. She was sent for a head CT scan, which showed no intracranial mass. Which of the following is the likely cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point towards a diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri or idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and it is caused by vitamin A toxicity.

Toxicity occurs when the accumulation of vitamin A goes beyond the capacity of intracellular binding proteins.

The unbound vitamin A causes membrane lysis and tissue damage.

Clinical features of hypervitaminosis A:

  • CNS - Headache, nausea, ataxia, anorexia, increased cerebrospinal fluid pressure aka pseudotumor cerebri
  • Liver - Hepatomegaly and hyperlipidemia.
  • Bones - Thickening of the long bones, hypercalcemia, soft tissue calcification.
  • Dermatological - Dryness, desquamation, alopecia
  • Teratogenesis - It can cause congenital malformations in the developing fetus. Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug contraindicated in women of childbearing age unless indicated.

Other options:

Option A: Pyridoxine toxicity causes sensory neuropathy.

Option B: Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, dementia, and diarrhea.

Option C: Thiamine deficiency causes Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is a triad of ophthalmoplegia, global confusion, and ataxia.

Related Pearl: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

  • Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.
  •  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.
  • Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.
  • In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.
  • Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.
  • Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).
  • Prognosis:
    • Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.
    • Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.

questions.text: A post-myocardial infarction patient developed acute onset exertional dyspnea. Chest x-ray revealed pulmonary edema. Which of the following auscultation findings will point towards acute mitral regurgitation (MR)?
questions.solution:
The finding on auscultation that points towards diagnosis of acute mitral regurgitation (MR) is systolic murmur ending before S2. 

Post-myocardial infarction (MI) patients can develop papillary muscle rupture leading to the regurgitation of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium (LA). Since it is an acutely occuring event, the LA has no time to compensate and become compliant. This leads to two outcomes:

  • Pulmonary congestion due to large volume of regurgitant blood compared to non-compliant LA.
  • Murmur ending before S2.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who is a laborer presents with progressive weakness of the legs. He says that the weakness is more in the morning and as the day progresses, it improves for a while usually. He is a known smoker. Examination reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Paraneoplastic syndrome seen in lung adenocarcinoma
Incremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). Incremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation is a feature of this condition.

LEMS is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach) release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers.

Antibodies directed against the P/Q voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) interfere with the normal calcium flux required for the release of acetylcholine.

Approximately 50% of LEMS cases are associated with malignancy, mainly small cell lung cancer (SCLC). 

Most patients with LEMS present with symptoms as slowly progressive proximal muscle weakness. In LEMS, the weakness improves for a while after exertion. Diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes help differentiate between LEMS and myasthenia gravis.

An increase in the compound muscle action potential (CAMP) amplitude >100% after exercise or with high-frequency repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered to be of diagnostic significance.

questions.text: The electrocardiogram of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows broad QRS complexes, rSR' pattern in lead V1, and a curved S wave which is wider than the R wave in lead V6. This points to a diagnosis of right bundle branch block (RBBB).

To make a diagnosis of RBBB, the following three criteria should be met:

  1. QRS duration >120 ms.
  2. rSR' pattern present in leads V1 or V2. The R' is usually wider than the initial R wave.
  3. S wave of greater duration than the R wave in leads V6.

Bundle branch blocks occur due to a block in the conduction in the right or the left bundle system below the AV node. RBBB is often seen in patients with no underlying heart disease, while left bundle branch block (LBBB) is seen associated with ischemic heart disease, cardiomyopathy and valvular heart disease.

Other options:

Option B: The ECG findings suggestive of LBBB include:

  • QRS duration >120 ms
  • Broad, notched, or slurred R wave in leads V5 or V6
  • Absent q waves in leads V5 or V6
  • QS (no preceding R wave) or rS (small R wave but deep S wave) complexes in lead V1

The image below shows QRS patterns in the right and left bundle branch blocks:

 

Option C: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome occurs due to an abnormal conduction pathway in the cardiac tissues between the atria and ventricles. ECG will show the following features:

  • A shortened PR interval 
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex 

The image below shows the delta waves in WPW syndrome

 

Option D: In ventricular bigeminy, every normal QRS complex is followed by a premature ventricular contraction, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents to the emergency department with hypertension, palpitations, nausea, vomiting, and absence of knee jerk. Upon eliciting the history, he mentions that  2 hours back, he had consumed seeds of the plant shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this poisoning?

choices.text: The root of the plant resembles horse-radish root.
The plant is also called as 'bish', 'bikh' or 'mitha zaher'.
'Hippus,' which is the alternate opening and closure of eyelids, is a characteristic feature.

questions.solution:
Hippus, i.e. alternate dilatation and constriction of pupils, followed by complete dilation, is a characteristic feature.

The causative plant is aconite. It is also called 'bish', 'bikh', or 'mitha zaher'. It is a cardiac poison. The root resembles a horse-radish root.

Signs and symptoms

Symptoms generally appear within 30 to 90 minutes after ingestion of the poison and last up to approximately 30 hours. 

Some of the typical features of aconitine poisoning:

  • Cardiovascular – Palpitation, hypertension, ventricular ectopics/ arrhythmias
  • Gastrointestinal – Nausea, salivation, pain in the stomach, vomiting, and diarrhea
  • Neurological – Paraesthesia, tingling, and numbness in the lips, mouth, tongue, and pharynx. Followed by profuse sweating, weakness impending paralysis of the extremities and/or seizures.
  • Deep tendon reflexes may be absent.
  • Eye – There may be difficulty in vision due to hippus, which means initially there is alternate dilatation and constriction of pupils, followed by complete dilation.
  • The conscious state of the victim may also be reduced.
  • Hypertensive, sustained, ventricular tachyarrhythmias are the direct cause of death. Manifestations of acidosis and hypokalemia are also often seen.

 

The images below show the aconite plant, seeds, and root, respectively.

questions.text: A neonate presented with gasping and cyanosis after an episode of vigorous crying in the morning. Chest x-ray showed the following finding. Which cardiac valve is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of a neonate having cyanosis after an episode of vigorous crying, and chest X-ray showing a "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, are suggestive of a cyanotic heart disease called Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The pulmonary valve is affected in this condition.

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with the following four components:

  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow obstruction. In mild degrees, the symptoms become pronounced as the baby grows due to RV infundibular hypertrophy and may present with heart failure. In severe degrees, pulmonary blood flow predominantly depends on the ductus arteriosus. As soon as the duct closes, the baby presents with cyanosis and circulatory collapse in the neonatal period.

The image given below shows the cardinal features seen in TOF:


Clinical features include significant hypercyanotic spells in infants which are characterized by hyperpnea, cyanosis, and gasping followed by syncope. The spells occur most frequently in the morning on initial awakening or after episodes of vigorous crying. These spells are due to a prolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow resulting in severe systemic hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.

Older children present with exertional dyspnea and assume a squatting position to relieve the dyspneic episode after which the child can resume activity.

The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex. The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively oligemic due to diminished pulmonary blood flow. The below image shows the chest X-ray findings:

questions.text: In a test of significance, the p value obtained was 0.023. Based on the significance of the observed difference in the study, what is your conclusion?

choices.text: Null hypothesis is accepted, and the study hypothesis is rejected.
Null hypothesis is rejected, and the study hypothesis is accepted.
Null hypothesis is accepted, and the study hypothesis is accepted.
Null hypothesis is rejected, and the study hypothesis is also rejected.

questions.solution:
• By convention, if the p value is ≤ 0.05, the difference is said to be statistically significant.
  • Therefore, the null hypothesis is rejected, and the study hypothesis is accepted.

questions.text: A male patient is brought to the emergency room with a gunshot injury to his knee. On surgical exploration, you see damage to the structure marked in the image given below. Identify the correct statement regarding the structure marked.

choices.text: The marked structure is the femoral artery.
It is the continuation of the profunda femoris artery.
The tibial nerve crosses medial to lateral to this artery.
It divides into the anterior and posterior tibial artery.

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the popliteal artery in the popliteal fossa. It divides into the anterior and posterior tibial arteries.

The popliteal artery is a continuation of the femoral artery and gives anterior and posterior tibial artery branches.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice bulbous swelling in his toes, as seen in the image below. A similar finding is not noted in his fingers. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
Since the given image shows clubbing involving the toes and the fingers are spared, the patient has differential clubbing. Therefore, he is likely to have patent ductus arteriosus.

Differential clubbing refers to the clubbing of toes but not of the fingers. It is a rare sign that indicates patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with Eisenmenger syndrome.

In COPD, there is no clubbing. In case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD, then the possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterised by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Patent ductus arteriosus (causes differential clubbing)
    • Aortic aneurysm (infected abdominal aortic aneurysm can also cause differential clubbing)
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing:

  • Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas, in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window is obliterated. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

questions.text: During your pediatric rotation, you observe a pediatrician perform the following test on a newborn to check for the neuromuscular maturity. What test is being done?
questions.solution:
The sign shown is the Scarf sign. It is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score.

Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest,

  • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline.
  • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline.

Neuromuscular criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  • Posture
  • Square window (wrist)
  • Arm recoil
  • Popliteal angle
  • Scarf sign
  • Heel to ear

questions.text:
Which of the following sections of the Indian penal code (IPC) deal with 'Assault' and 'Sexual assault (Assault on women to insult their modesty),' respectively?

S-Section
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C, i.e. S. 351, S. 354.

Section 351 of the IPC - This section defines assault as applying or even attempting to apply force to the body of another individual in a hostile manner. This section can be applied irrespective of whether the assault causes any injury or not. Even hostile gestures such as raising a fist at someone in a hostile manner can constitute assault.

Section 354 of the IPC - This section covers assault or use of force on women in order to insult their modesty. The punishment may be imprisonment of 1–5 years and a fine. The other offenses under section 354 of the IPC are as follows:

354-A: Sexual harassment involving physical contact, advances, demands sexual favors, making sexual remarks, showing the victim pornography
354-B: Assaulting or forcing a woman to disrobe 
354-C: Voyeurism
354-D: Stalking or following a woman to force interaction or monitoring using the internet, email, or any electronic communication.

questions.text: An obese diabetic female patient is posted for surgery. The anesthetist performs a BURP maneuver during intubation. Identify the true statement regarding this maneuver.

choices.text: It is a technique of internal laryngeal manipulation.
It is useful for rapid-sequence induction.
It is a method of assessment of airway.
In this technique, pressure is applied on the thyroid cartilage.

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding the BURP maneuver is that pressure is applied to the thyroid cartilage.

BURP is a technique of external laryngeal manipulation of the airway during intubation for better visualization of the larynx. This involves Backward, Upward, and Rightward Pressure on the thyroid cartilage.

The illustration shown below shows the BURP maneuver.

Other options : 

Option B: The BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

Option C: BURP is not a method of assessment of the airway. Various methods of airway assessments are Mallampati grading, Cormack and Lehane grading, and Wilson’s scoring.

questions.text: A child in your unit is admitted with acute bronchiolitis. Which of the following is the most common etiological agent responsible for this condition during infancy?
questions.solution:
Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease in children younger than 2 years. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the most likely etiological agent and is responsible for more than 50% of cases.

Acute bronchiolitis refers to airway inflammation and obstruction of the lower respiratory tract.

Clinical features of bronchiolitis include fever, cough, fine inspiratory crackles, expiratory wheezes, and breathing difficulty. Cyanosis may be seen in severe cases.

Radiographs may be normal in some patients. In the majority of them, there will be interstitial infiltrates, hyper-expansion of the chest, and peribronchial thickening. 

Management is mainly conservative. Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen. Rarely, a child might develop respiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasive ventilation.

questions.text: A wildlife photographer presents with complaints of fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He also gives the history of insect bite at the site of skin lesion. A blood test reveals a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins.  Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing eschar at the bite site along with a positive Weil-Felix reaction with OX K agglutinins is suggestive of scrub typhus. It is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Scrub typhus is also known as chigger-borne typhus which is caused by O. tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. 

The incubation period is 1–3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains—Proteus vulgaris - OX 19 and OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus.

OX K is agglutinated only in scrub typhus.

questions.text:
Given below are the branches of the maxillary artery. Identify the correct statement regarding their origin.

  2. Posterior superior alveolar artery
  3. Middle superior alveolar artery

choices.text: 1 arises from the 1st part of maxillary artery.
2, 3, 4 arise from the 2nd part of maxillary artery.
1 arises from the 3rd part of maxillary artery.
1, 2, 3, 4 arise from the 1st part of maxillary artery.

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option A-Artery 1 arises from the 1st part of the maxillary artery.

Arteries 2, 3, and 4 arise from the 3rd part of the maxillary artery.

Inferior alveolar artery arises as a direct branch from the 1st part of the maxillary artery.

Posterior superior alveolar artery arises as a direct branch from the 3rd part of the maxillary artery.

Anterior superior alveolar and middle superior alveolar arteries arise from the infraorbital artery, which is a direct branch from the 3rd part of the maxillary artery.

questions.text:
A patient was given a continuous infusion of an anesthetic agent for 48 hours. On examination, his heart rate was 54 beats/min. Laboratory investigations showed hyperlipidemia and ABG consistent with metabolic acidosis. What is the anesthetic agent used in this patient?

ABG - Arterial blood gas analysis
questions.solution:
The given features point towards the diagnosis of propofol infusion syndrome. Therefore, the anesthetic agent used in this patient is propofol.

Propofol infusion syndrome is a rare, but lethal, syndrome. It is seen when the dose of propofol infusion is > 4 mg/kg/hour for 48 hours or longer. This syndrome is common in children and critically ill adults.

Prolonged use of propofol causes defects in mitochondrial metabolism and electron transport chain function.

Clinical features of propofol infusion syndrome:

  • Acute refractory bradycardia, leading to asystole in the presence of one or more of the following:
    • Metabolic acidosis (base deficit >10 mmol/L)
    • Rhabdomyolysis - due to muscle injury
    • Hyperlipidemia - due to defective medium-chain acyl CoA metabolism
    • Enlarged or fatty liver
  • Other features
    • Cardiomyopathy with acute cardiac failure
    • Skeletal myopathy
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Lipemia

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient, who had undergone renal transplantation, presents to you with severe pain along the back of the leg above the heels. He reports that he has been taking some antibiotics without any doctor's prescription. You suspect Achilles tendon rupture. It is usually seen as a side effect of which of the following antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Achilles tendon rupture and tendinitis are associated side effects of quinolones like ciprofloxacin.

Elderly patients (>60 years), patients on corticosteroids, and solid organ transplant recipients are at higher risk of developing this risk factor. 

Fluoroquinolones inhibit topoisomerase IV in gram-positive bacteria. Normally, during replication, to prevent excessive positive supercoiling of the strands, DNA gyrase nicks double-stranded DNA and introduces negative supercoils. Fluoroquinolones, by inhibiting DNA gyrase (in gram-negative bacteria), result in the production of damaged DNA. This is finally digested by exonucleases, resulting in bactericidal action.

Fluoroquinolones are used in the treatment of urinary tract infections, prostatitis, and gastrointestinal, and respiratory infections, and as a second-line drug in anti-tubercular therapy. They are avoided in children and pregnant women.

Adverse effects of fluoroquinolones are arthralgia, tendon rupture, Clostridium difficile colitis, dysglycemia, prolonged QT interval, rashes, hallucinations, delirium, and seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following types of leprosy would have the following finding as its most prominent histologic feature?
questions.solution:
The finding marked with red arrows in the given image is Grenz zone and it is prominently seen in the case of lepromatous leprosy.

The Grenz zone is a narrow area of the papillary dermis uninvolved by the underlying pathology. The Grenz zone is most prominent in lepromatous leprosy as there are scarce granulomas to fill this space. It may also be seen in the borderline spectrum, but is not necessarily characteristic.

Dermal tuberculoid granulomas, consisting of groups of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are found in tuberculoid leprosy. The granulomas are elongated and generally run parallel to the surface, following neurovascular bundles. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone.

Grenz zone is also seen in Granuloma faciale and B cell lymphomas.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ENT OPD with complaints of ear pain associated with impaired hearing. She has occasionally experienced tinnitus as well. questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of hearing loss. On detailed examination, he was found to have a defect in the nerve shown in the image given below. This nerve forms an important connection to the auditory pathway. Identify the type of neuron.
questions.solution:
The image given here depicts a bipolar neuron.

Neurons are classified based on the number of processes as:

  • Unipolar, e.g., mesencephalic nucleus
  • Pseudo-unipolar, e.g., sensory ganglia or spinal ganglia.
  • Bipolar, e.g., spiral and vestibular ganglia, and bipolar neurons of the retina.
  • Multipolar, e.g., neurons in cerebrum and cerebellum.

questions.text: An obese and intellectually impaired patient whose hands are shown in the image below is brought by his relatives to the OPD. Blood investigations show low calcium, high phosphorous, and parathormone levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing short metacarpals (brachydactyly) and the accompanying clinical scenario of obesity and intellectual disability with low calcium, high phosphorous, and high parathormone levels are suggestive of pseudohypoparathyroidism.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism is an inherited disorder that is characterized by hypocalcemia and characteristic skeletal features, known as Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). It is due to the loss of function mutation in genes encoding the alpha subunit of the stimulatory G-protein Gsα. This blocks the action of PTH, leading to reduced serum calcium and increased serum phosphate. AHO features include short stature, short metacarpals and metatarsals (brachydactyly), round facies, intellectual impairment, and heterotropic calcifications.

Although serum calcium is low and serum phosphate is high (like hypoparathyroidism), PTH levels are also found to be elevated, and thus this disorder is termed pseudohypoparathyroidism. Urinary cAMP excretion is low because PTH is unable to act on its downstream pathways.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin D deficiency occurs due to inadequate intake of dairy products rich in vitamin D, lack of vitamin supplementation, and decreased sunlight exposure. It results in a mild decrease in calcium levels, elevated parathormone levels due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, and low phosphate levels.

Option B: Hypoparathyroidism is due to the decreased production of parathormone from the parathyroid glands. It is characterized by low calcium and low parathormone levels with elevated phosphate. Clinical features of hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism include paresthesias, seizures, carpopedal spasm, bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and prolongation of the QT interval.

Option D: Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism is also associated with AHO features. However, serum calcium, phosphate, and PTH levels are normal in these patients. Urinary cAMP is also normal.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant was brought to the pediatric emergency department with recurrent seizures and hypoglycemia. His family history revealed the sudden death of his sibling at the age of 3 months. Labs showed increased dicarboxylic acid in blood and urine. Which of the following is the pathophysiology behind this clinical manifestation?

choices.text: Impaired alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids
Impaired beta-oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids
Impaired omega oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids
Impaired peroxisomal oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency in which, there is impaired beta-oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids. This leads to the accumulation of dicarboxylic acids leading to dicarboxylic aciduria. It is characterized by:

  • Excretion of C6-C10 ω-dicarboxylic acids (medium-chain) in the urine.
  • Nonketotic hypoglycemia: due to the lack of ATP and acetyl CoA from β-oxidation (which is an activator of pyruvate carboxylase) to support gluconeogenesis.

Defects in medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase have been identified as a cause of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

Omega-oxidation is an alternative way of fatty acid oxidation in the body when the beta-oxidation enzymes are either saturated or defective. Omega oxidation converts excess fatty acids to dicarboxylic acids that are soluble and hence can be excreted out via urine.

Other options:

Option A: Impaired Alpha oxidation leads to Refsum’s disease. The manifestations of classic adult Refsum's disease include retinitis pigmentosa, peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, ichthyosis, anosmia, deafness and cardiac arrhythmias.

Option C: Medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase deficiency will lead to increased (not impaired) utilization of the omega oxidation pathway, resulting in the overproduction of dicarboxylic acids.

Option D: Impaired peroxisomal oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) causes Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome. It is a rare inherited disorder characterized by the absence of peroxisomal enzymes in all tissues leading to the accumulation of C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue. The clinical manifestation of Zellweger syndrome includes:

  • Facial deformities resembling Down syndrome (Mongoloid facies, Hypertelorism, Frontal bossing, Upslanting palpebral fissure)
  • Brush field spots
  • Hypotonia and hyporeflexia
  • Seizures
  • Neurodevelopmental delay
  • Liver enlargement

questions.text:
Given below is a graph of the 24-hour levels of a hormone. Identify the correct set of conditions that stimulate the release of this hormone.
Options Glucose Free fatty Acid Amino Acid
A ↓ ↓ ↑
B ↓ ↓ ↓
C ↑ ↑ ↓
D ↑ ↓  ↓
questions.solution:
The hormone depicted in the graph shows pulsatile secretion, with an increase during strenuous exercise and early periods of sleep, indicating that it is growth hormone (GH). The conditions that stimulate the release of GH are given in option A - a decrease in blood glucose and free fatty acid levels and an increase in blood amino acid (especially arginine) levels. 

Growth hormone is secreted by the somatotropes located in the anterior pituitary. The levels of growth hormones show diurnal variation as well as variation across different age groups. Adolescents have the highest circulating levels of growth hormone, followed by children and adults. The levels are relatively low during the day and the pulsatile release of this hormone occurs during sleep.

Stimuli that increase GH secretion:

  • Exercise
  • Going to sleep
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Decreased FFA levels
  • Increased blood amino acid levels 
  • Stressful stimuli (including various psychological stresses)
  • High Protein Meal
  • Glucagon
  • Estrogens and androgens

Stimuli that decrease GH secretion:

  • Increased blood Glucose
  • Cortisol
  • Medroxyprogesterone
  • Growth hormone and IGF-I

GH can act directly on the cells or mediate its actions through insulin-like growth factors (IGF).

Actions of growth hormone:

  • Growth of cartilage, bones, and organs.
  • Increases amino acid uptake and protein synthesis in the cells and decreases protein breakdown.
  • Diabetogenic action: Increases the hepatic glucose release and decreases the glucose uptake by muscles and fat.
  • Increases fat utilization. It is ketogenic and increases circulating free fatty acid levels.

Since somatostatin inhibits the release of GH, somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide are used in the treatment of acromegaly.

questions.text: While calculating the dependency ratio for a certain demographic population, an epidemiologist concludes that the particular population is at a demographic bonus. Which of the following is true about the population under evaluation?

choices.text: Decline in dependency ratio and increase in life expectancy
Rise in dependency ratio and decrease in fertility
Rise in dependency ratio and increase in life expectancy
Decline in dependency ratio and decrease in fertility

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, demographic bonus refers to the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility.

Dependency ratio:

In any given population, persons above the age of 65 years and children below the age of 15 years are considered as dependents. The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15 – 65 years and is calculated using the formula given below:

Total dependency ratio = (Total population below 15 years and above 65 years) x 100/Total population in the age group of 15 – 64 years.

It is also called societal dependency ratio.

The total dependency ratio can also be divided into young age dependency ratio and old-age dependency ratio. Potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 years per older person aged 65 or more. This is the inverse of the old age dependency ratio.

Other important terms based on dependency ratio:

  • The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility.
  • The term demographic burden is used to denote the increase in total dependency ratio during any period of time mostly caused by increased old-age dependency ratio.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a swelling in the lower abdomen as seen in the image below. On examination, it is seen that the swelling was reducible and a CT scan showed the presence of a defect in the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis muscle with the hernia lying deep to the external oblique aponeurosis. This presentation is typical of what type of hernia?
questions.solution:
This clinical presentation is typical of a spigelian hernia.

Spigelian hernias arise from a defect in the spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis muscle. The fascia extends between the transversus muscle and the lateral border of the rectus sheath from the costal margin to the groin, where it blends into the conjoint tendon.

Most spigelian hernias appear below the level of the umbilicus near the edge of the rectus sheath. 

In young patients, these hernias usually contain extraperitoneal fat only and they present with intermittent pain due to pinching of the fat. A lump may or may not be palpable because the fatty hernia is small and the overlying external oblique is intact. In older patients, there is often a peritoneal sac and they can become very large in size. They generally present with a reducible swelling at the edge of the rectus sheath and may have symptoms of intermittent obstruction.

The diagnosis can be made from the location of the symptoms and is confirmed by CT. If the hernia is reducible, ultrasonography can be done.

Surgery is recommended for treatment because of the predisposition to strangulation, it can either be open or laparoscopic. In open surgery, a skin crease is made over the hernia, and the sac is usually visible once the external oblique is opened. The sac and contents are dealt with and the defect in the Spigelian fascia is repaired by suture or mesh laid deep to the external oblique aponeurosis. 

Laparoscopy is useful if no sac is palpable. However, in young patients with a hernia containing only extraperitoneal fat with no hernia seen from within the peritoneum, the peritoneum can be incised and the extraperitoneal plane explored for the small defect, which can then be closed by either suture or mesh. When an intraperitoneal sac is present, a laparoscopic repair can be performed using either the intra-peritoneal onlay of mesh (IPOM) or transabdominal pre-peritoneal mesh repair (TAPP) technique.

Other options:

Option A: Epigastric hernia arises through the linea alba anywhere between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus. They begin with a transverse split in the midline raphe. Epigastric hernia defects are usually less than 1 cm in diameter and commonly contain only extraperitoneal fat, which gradually enlarges, spreading in the subcutaneous plane. More than one hernia may be present and it usually occurs in men between the second and fourth decades. They can become very painful, due to the partial strangulation of the contents. A soft midline swelling can often be felt and it may be tender. It is unlikely to be reducible because of the narrow neck.

The image below shows an epigastric hernia.

Option C: Incisional hernia arises through a defect in the abdominal wall in the region of a postoperative scar. Incisional hernias have been reported more commonly after laparotomy incisions than laparoscopic port-site incisions. Predisposing factors include patient-related factors like obesity, malnutrition, immunosuppression or steroid therapy, wound factors like wound infection, and surgical factors like the use of inappropriate suture material, and incorrect suture placement. They appear as a localized swelling involving a portion of the surgical scar. The skin overlying large hernias may become thin and atrophic so that peristalsis may be seen in the underlying intestine. Vascular damage to the skin may lead to dermatitis. Most incisional hernias are broad-necked and therefore the risk of strangulation is low.

The image below shows an incisional hernia.

Option D: Obturator hernia occurs through the obturator canal between the superior pubic ramus and obturator membrane. It is seen mostly in elderly females and patients usually present with features of intestinal obstruction, which is often confirmed only on laparotomy. In a few cases, it is seen as a swelling in Scarpa's triangle deep to the pectineus muscle, with the limb kept in flexed and abducted position and any movement of the limb resulting in pain. Howship-Romberg sign is positive in about half the cases; this involves referred pain in the knee joint through the geniculate branch of the obturator nerve, which not only signifies an obturator hernia but also strangulation.

questions.text: An infant after ingestion of protein-rich food develops vomiting, acidosis, and convulsions. His urine has a typical sweaty feet odor. Catabolism of which amino acid is affected here?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of isovaleric acidemia. Sweaty-feet odor or rancid cheese odor may be present. It is a defect in the catabolism of leucine.

Isovaleric acidemia is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase, which affects the breakdown pathway of leucine leading to the accumulation of intermediates. Excess protein intake leads to the accumulation of isovaleryl-CoA, which is hydrolyzed to isovalerate and excreted. 

These intermediates are responsible for clinical features such as vomiting, acidosis, lethargy, and convulsions, which can progress to coma and death. Laboratory findings include ketoacidosis, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and hypoglycemia. The diagnosis is established by demonstrating marked elevations of isovaleric acid metabolites in urine.

The treatment of choice is L-carnitine.

Defective metabolism of all three branched amino acids, i.e. leucine, isoleucine, and valine, leads to maple syrup urine disease. In this condition, α-ketoacid decarboxylase complex is defective. 

A defect in tyrosine catabolism causes tyrosinemia, which is manifested as liver failure.

questions.text: Which of the following marked distances is described as the caliber of a rifled gun?
questions.solution:
The caliber of a rifled gun is described as the marked distance C in the image. Caliber is measured as the distance between two diametrically opposite lands.

It is the internal dimension of the barrel and is measured in millimeters or inches. 

Note: For a smooth barrel weapon, it is measured as the distance between two diametrically opposite points on the inner circumference.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presented with a history of poor school performance. Psychological assessments revealed intellectual disability. A history of poor intellectual function is present in the paternal family. After extensive evaluation, a diagnosis of Fragile X Syndrome was made. This condition occurs due to _____ CGG repeats causing _____ mutation of the FMR1 gene.

GOF: Gain Of Function

LOF: Loss Of Function
questions.solution:
Fragile X syndrome occurs due to 200-4000 CGG repeats causing LOF mutation of the FMR1 gene.

Normally, the FMR1 gene is methylated and silenced, and the number of CGG repeats remains <55. However, abnormalities in this gene lead to the accumulation of CGG-containing FMR1 mRNAs, which are toxic to the cell.

Depending on the type of mutation, there are 2 distinct syndromes:

  • Fragile X ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) and Fragile X–associated primary ovarian failure: 55-200 repeats (premutation) which causes gain of function.
  • Fragile X syndrome (FXs): 200- 4000 repeats (full mutation) leading to loss of function.

More than half the individuals with FXTAS develop a progressive neurodegenerative syndrome starting in their 6th decade. It is characterized by intentional tremors and cerebellar ataxia and may progress to Parkinsonism.

Fragile X–associated primary ovarian failure

Women affected with fragile X–associated primary ovarian failure have menstrual irregularities and decreased fertility. FSH levels are elevated, and antimüllerian hormone levels are decreased, which are markers of declining ovarian function. They also develop menopause approximately 5 years earlier than controls.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents with nausea, vomiting,  abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Stool examination revealed the eggs of Balantidium coli. What is the organ of locomotion for this organism?
questions.solution:
The organ of locomotion for Balantidium coli is the cilia. 

Balantidium coli is the only ciliated protozoan and is present as a commensal in the large intestine. It does not cause infection in healthy individuals. However, certain predisposing factors such as malnourishment, alcoholism, concurrent infection with Trichuris trichiura, or bacterial infection can cause clinical infection.

Clinical patients present with mucosal ulcers, diarrhea, frank dysentery, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. 

Diagnosis is by stool examination, which shows the presence of trophozoites in diarrheic feces and cysts in formed stools. Trophozoites are large size, with a macronucleus and rapid-revolving motility, while cysts are round with a macronucleus.

The image given below shows trophozoite of Balantidium coli.

questions.text:
A chronic alcoholic patient presented with hematemesis. After the failure of all the treatment options, he underwent the following procedure for the management of portal hypertension. The surgeon decided to perform this procedure as it minimizes the risk of hepatic encephalopathy. Identify the shunt depicted in the image below.

[IVC-Inferior vena cava, PV-Portal vein, SV-Splenic vein, LRV-Left renal vein]
questions.solution:
The image shows Warre shunt (distal lienorenal shunt). This is the only selective shunt out of the four options given hence it has the least risk of hepatic encephalopathy. 

TIPS(Transjugular Intravenous Porto Systemic Shunt):

The main indication of TIPS is variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. A guidewire is inserted via the internal jugular vein and superior vena cava into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The major complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPS is portal vein occlusion.

Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure >5 mmHg.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a treatment option whereby a percutaneous connection is created within the liver, between the portal and systemic circulations, to reduce portal pressure in patients with complications related to portal hypertension.

Complications of TIPS procedure:

  • Intraoperative complications- capsular hemorrhage
  • Early complication- hepatic encephalopathy
  • Late complication- recurrent variceal bleed
  • Delayed complication- total shunt occlusion

Shunts for portal hypertension:

  • Non-selective shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted
    • Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    • ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)
    • Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
  • Selective shunt- only splenic blood is shunted
    • Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)
    • Inokuchi shunt 

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text:
An unclaimed dead body was brought for forensic examination. A postmortem examination of the sternum was done to find out the age of the dead body. What is the sequence in which the following parts of the sternum fuse with each other? (First to last)

Manubrium-X

Body/Body segments-Y

Xiphoid-Z
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option D-YY - ZY - XY

Body segments-(YY)(14-25 years) - Xiphoid with body-(ZY)(40-45 years) - Manubrium with body-(XY)(60 years).

The sternum is formed from the fusion of manubrium, the body, and the xiphoid process. The fusion of the 4 pieces of the body of the sternum occurs from below upwards, followed by its fusion to the xiphoid process and then fusion of manubrium to the fused sternum.

Joints 

Age of fusion
Fusion of manubrium with body

Usually above 50-60 years 
Fusion of body segments  14-25 years from below upwards
Fusion of xiphoid process with body 40-45 years

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with headaches, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI findings are shown in the image below. Considering the sign seen in the image, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of headache, seizures, focal neurological deficits, and the MRI showing a dural tail sign are suggestive of meningioma.

The dural tail sign refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumour, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases). However, it may also be seen in the following non-meningiomatous lesions such as schwannoma, sarcoidosis, primary CNS lymphoma, metastasis, and chloroma.

The image given below shows axial (A) and sagittal (B) contrast-enhanced MRI images of the brain. The arrows point towards the thickening and enhancements of the dura, tapering away from the mass and resembling a tail (dural tail sign).

Radiological features of meningioma:

  • Angiography may reveal a spoke wheel appearance, or a dense, homogeneous, and persistent blush representing meningeal blood supply to the tumor.
  • CT usually reveals a hyperdense extra-axial mass with or without calcification.
  • MRI may show capping cysts, vasogenic edema, and a dural tail sign.
  • PET shows high uptake of 68Ga-DOTATOC, a somatostatin receptor-targeted ligand.

Other options:

Option A: Extradural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the skull and dura mater. It appears as a lenticular, biconvex lesion in acute cases or as a crescentic-shaped lesion in chronic cases.

Option B: Subdural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the dura and arachnoid mater. It appears as a crescentic concave in acute cases or an elliptical lesion in chronic cases.

Option C: Craniopharyngioma is a benign suprasellar tumor arising from squamous epithelial remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is commonly located in the hypothalamic region. On MRI, it usually appears as a cystic lesion. It may also present as a mixed cystic or solid lesion. The solid components show intense contrast enhancement.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented with pain in her lower abdomen for the past 4 months. She informed that she has had fibroids since a long time. The radiological investigation showed fibroids looking like womb stones. What is the type of degeneration that has occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Womb-stone appearance is seen in the calcareous degeneration of fibroids.

The blood vessels run in the periphery of fibroids. Along the course of these vessels, phosphates and carbonates of lime are deposited. This leads to calcareous degeneration.

Since these depositions are arranged in the periphery in a scattered manner, it gives an appearance of womb-stones of a graveyard surrounding the fibroids.

The best examples of calcareous degeneration are those in old patients with long-standing myomas. 

Hyaline, cystic, and fatty degenerations occur in the central areas of fibroids and have no clinical significance. They are caused by the diminished vascularity in large fibroids.

questions.text: MEN1 syndrome includes all of the following tumors except:
questions.solution:
MEN 1 syndrome does not include pheochromocytomas. 

Mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene lead to MEN 1, also called Wermer syndrome.  It is characterized by

  • Parathyroid hyperplasia or adenoma
  • Pancreas - pancreatic polypeptidoma 
  • Pituitary - the most common anterior pituitary tumor is prolactinoma

MEN type 2 is classified into MEN 2A and MEN 2B. 

MEN 2A is also called Sipple syndrome and characterized by

  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia.

MEN 2B is characterized by

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Pheochromocytoma.
  • Mucosal neuromas of lips and tongue, intestinal ganglioneuromas, marfanoid habitus, and lax joints.
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia is absent. 

 

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs

  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought with complaints of ataxia and signs of increased intracranial tension. A report of the radiological investigation which is performed on her is given below. What is this investigation used to assess/based on?
questions.solution:
The investigation on which the report shown in the image above is magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy. It is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information.

The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

Other options:

Option B: Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) is a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technique in which contrast within the image is based on the microscopic motion of water. Thus, it is more sensitive to early changes of cytotoxic or vasogenic damage at the cellular level than traditional MRI measurements such as T1 or T2 relaxation rates.

Option C: The blood oxygen level–dependent (BOLD) effect forms the basis for fMRI (functional MRI).

Option D: Microhemorrhages are detected by the susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) technique of MRI.

questions.text: A child presents with bilateral abrupt onset proptosis. There is associated lid ecchymosis and a superior orbital mass. The biopsy of the mass shows a round-cell tumor. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on lid ecchymosis, round cell tumor mass and an abrupt bilateral proptosis is neuroblastoma.

Neuroblastoma is a common childhood malignancy arising from the neural crest dervied sympathetic nervous system, mostly in the abdomen. It metastatizes to the orbit thus resulting in bilateral abrupt onset proptosis.

There is associated lid ecchymosis which is very characteristic of neuroblastoma.

The histology of the tumor will show small round blue cells which are immature neural cells. They are also found in 

  • Rhabdomyosarcoma- desmin positive
  • Retinoblastoma- synaptophysin positive

It carries a very poor prognosis since it has undergone metastasis when proptosis is noted.

Other options:

Option A: Capillary hemangioma will have painless unilateral (more common than bilateral) proptosis. The biopsy would show dilated sinusoidal spaces as seen in hemangioma and not round cells.

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma also has round cells in biopsy but it will cause unilateral proptosis and there will be no associated lid ecchymosis.

Option D: Orbital cellulitis would have an antecedant history of trauma or sinus infection leading to proptosis. There will be no round cell tumor.

questions.text: The chest x-ray of a patient who presented with fever and cough with expectoration is shown below. Following the discussion, a lincosamide antibiotic is prescribed. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this antibiotic?

choices.text: Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis
Binding to 30S subunit and inhibiting protein synthesis
Binding to 50S subunit and inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.solution:
Clindamycin, a lincosamide is used in the management of lung abscess and anaerobic lung and pleural space infections. Clindamycin is a congener of lincomycin and binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes and inhibits protein synthesis.

Clindamycin also inhibits toxin production of C. perfringens and thus it is used as an adjunctive agent in necrotizing fasciitis or gas gangrene. It is also used topically for acne.

Adverse effects include diarrhea and a high risk of superinfection with C. difficile. 

Option A: Inhibitors of bacterial cell wall synthesis are penicillins, bacitracin, vancomycin, fosfomycin etc

Option B: Glycyclines and tetracyclines are antibiotics that bind to the 30S subunit of ribosomes and inhibit protein synthesis.

Option D: Sulfonamides are inhibitors of dihydropteroate synthase, thus impairing the folic acid pathway of bacteria.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents with a blackish mass on the skin of his arm. Suspecting a neoplastic growth, the surgeon orders a biopsy of the lesion and the following is the result shown in the image. Classify the following lesion according to both Breslow's and Clarke's grading systems.
questions.solution:
The lesion is classified as Breslow's Grade 3 (1.51 to 4 mm) and Clarke's Grade 4 (invades reticular dermis). 

Both Breslow's and Clark’s systems are used to stage melanoma on the basis of depth of invasion. The prognosis worsens with the depth. Breslow's thickness scale is based on the depth of invasion (in mm) measured from the granular layer of the epidermis to the base of the lesion. Clark's system is based on the layer of skin invaded by the melanoma.

questions.text:
A patient presents with a well-defined dusky lesion on his lips that recurs at the same site. What is the most likely implicated cause here?

NSAIDS = non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient having well-defined, dusky lesions that recur at the same spot points towards the diagnosis of a fixed drug eruption (FDE). The most likely implicated agent here is NSAIDS.

Fixed drug eruptions/reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They occur on lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation. They are usually solitary or few in number and recur at the same location. But, new lesions can occur on different body parts on re-exposure to the offending drug. FDE is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Paracetamol/NSAIDs are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

Drug‐specific clinical patterns have been reported. These include the following:

  • NSAID‐induced FDE - lips and genitals
  • Tetracycline and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole‐induced FDE - genitals
  • Metamizole‐induced FDE - trunk and extremities
  • Carbocysteine‐induced FDE - face

Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

The image below shows a well-defined hyperpigmented patch of a fixed drug eruption.

 

Other options:

Option B: Methimazole is not implicated in causing fixed-drug eruptions. 

Option C: Herpes simplex infection can cause similar lesions and is a close differential, but it can occur at any site and does not necessarily recur at the same site.

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus can cause bullous impetigo.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a workup for primary infertility. On hysterosalpingography, there was a bilateral cornual block. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the next step in management will be hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery.

Tubal contractions, particularly cornual spasms, can give an incorrect impression of proximal fallopian tube obstruction (a false-positive result) on hysterosalpingography. Laparoscopy with chromotubation is therefore considered to confirm the diagnosis of cornual spasm. Laparoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic in this condition.

Hysteroscopy is an operative procedure that provides an endoscopic view of the endometrial cavity and tubal ostia via the cervix, performed in the preovulatory phase. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic. It is the gold standard investigation for visualizing the uterine cavity and tubal ostia.

Therapeutic indications of hysteroscopy Diagnostic indications of hysteroscopy
  • Uterine septum
  • Asherman syndrome
  • Retained IUCD
  • Polypectomy
  • Submucous fibroid
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Tubal sterilization using sclerosing agents
  • To study the endocervical mucosal lining
  • Congenital malformations of the uterus
  • Endometrial tuberculosis
  • Misplaced IUCD
  • Endometrial lesions
  • Endometrial polyp
  • Asherman syndrome
  • Cornual tubal blockage

Contraindications to hysteroscopy are as follows:

  • Acute genital tract infection (Eg: genital herpes infection)
  • Viable intrauterine pregnancy
  • During menstruation, the view is obscured, and the infection rate is high.
  • Scarred uterus and enlarged uterus of size ≥ 12 weeks are relative contraindications.
  • Cervical stenosis can cause cervical tears and uterine perforation.
  • Cardiopulmonary disorder due to increased risk of fluid overload and pulmonary edema.
  • Known cases of cervical cancer

Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the evaluation of tubal factors in infertility, commonly done in the proliferative phase. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic. 

Diagnostic  Therapeutic (Operative)
  • Age >35 years
  • History of pelvic pain, dyspareunia, pelvic surgery, adhesions
  • Abnormal HSG
  • Failure to conceive after a reasonable period (6 months) with normal HSG
  • Women with comorbid pelvic pathology (PID, endometriosis)
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Reconstructive tubal surgery
  • Adhesiolysis
  • Fulguration of endometriotic implants
  • Ovarian drilling in PCOS
  • GIFT and ZIFT procedures

Benefits of laparoscopic evaluation:

  • Tubes: For detection of tubal patency, block (site and side), motility, hydrosalpinx change, peritubal adhesions, fimbrial agglutination
  • Ovaries: PCOS changes, endometriosis, PID, adhesions
  • Uterus: Anomalies, fibroids
  • Peritoneal factors: Adhesions, PID, endometriosis, tuberculosis
  • Therapy at the same sitting (as appropriate)

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with complaints of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. She also had frequent episodes of vomiting. A USG scan was done and is shown below. Which of the following is not recommended post-evacuation for this condition?

hCG - Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

choices.text: Allowing pregnancy after 6 months of monitoring
Initial hCG levels checked within 48 hours of evacuation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy and intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance, post evacuation.

Molar pregnancy may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG.  

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. Here post evacuation, Intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance. This is because there is increased risk of perforation during this period if an invasive mole is present.

Post-evacuation recommendations:

  • Anti-D immune globulin if Rh D-negative
  • Initiate effective contraception (IUD contraindicated)
  • Review pathology report
  • Serum hCG levels: within 48 h of evacuation, weekly until undetectable, then monthly for 6 months.

Pregnancy is allowed after 6 months following a negative hCG titer. However, it is advised to avoid pregnancy for 1 year, preferably 2 years, as a fresh pregnancy will interfere with the hCG titres.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has had 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen, with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of size 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
A clear ovarian cyst with size less than 7 cm in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely to be a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to follow up after 6–12 weeks and perform a repeat USG.

A simple unilocular cyst under 7 cm is often a functional cyst and should be observed. Most functional cysts resolve spontaneously within 4-6 months. A follow-up ultrasound will detect any persistent cyst, which may necessitate laparoscopic evaluation. To expedite resolution or to treat symptoms like pain and irregular menses, oral combined pills may be prescribed for 3-4 months in women of reproductive age.

Features of a functional cyst:

  • Related to temporary hormonal variation
  • Benign and rarely become complicated
  • Usually 6–8 cm in diameter
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Contains clear fluid, unless hemorrhage occurs
  • Lining epithelium corresponds to the functional epithelium of the unit from which they arise

Management of functional cysts in women of child-bearing age group is summarized in the flowchart attached below.

Other options: 

Option A: Tumour markers such as CA-125 and CEA are particulary useful in postmenopausal women suspected of having a malignant epithelial cell tumor.

Option C: If the cyst does not resolve spontaneoulsy it can be removed laparoscopically or by laparotomy.

Option D: Imaging modalities such as CT scan and MRI help to detect ovarian neoplasms and assist in staging of ovarian cancers.

questions.text: The rule of Hasse is not applicable for a fetus who is  _____ old.
questions.solution:
The rule of Hasse is used in the determination of the age of the fetus. It is used in the first five months of pregnancy.

This method involves measuring the length of the fetus from the crown to the heel in centimeters. The fetal age is given by the square root of the fetal length in the first five months of pregnancy.

Hasse's Modification of Morisson's Law: Beyond five months of pregnancy, the fetal length divided by five gives the approximate age.

questions.text: You enter the ENT operation theatre when a procedure is underway for a patient with fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball.  You notice the following instruments on the instruments tray. Which of the following is not an indication for the procedure performed with these instruments?
questions.solution:
The given image is of instruments commonly used in Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) operation. Lateral frontal sinus disease is a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery as the disease is inaccessible by endoscopic procedures.

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis).
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball or nasal polyp.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.

Contraindications to FESS:

  • Inexperience and lack of proper instrumentation.
  • Disease inaccessible by endoscopic procedures, e.g. lateral frontal sinus disease and stenosis of internal opening of frontal sinus.
  • Osteomyelitis.
  • Threatened intracranial or intraorbital complication.

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever and cough. On blood culture, the causative organism was found to be Haemophilus influenzae. Staphylococcus aureus is streaked across a blood agar containing the colonies of Hemophilus as shown in the image below. The phenomenon observed is because of the release of _____ due to hemolysis caused by S.aureus, which in turn ____ the growth of Hemophilus.
questions.solution:
The phenomenon observed in the above scenario is called satellitism. This phenomenon is because of the release of NAD due to hemolysis caused by Staphylococcus aureus, which in turn stimulates the growth of Haemophilus.

Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that is non-motile and non-spore-forming. 

When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus. 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

  • Factor V  is a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a coenzyme. and is heat labile
  • Factor X is hemin. It is required for cytochrome synthesis and the function of enzymes like catalase and peroxidase. It is heat stable.

When H. influenzae is cultured on the same plate as S. aureus. The closer the colonies of H. influenzae are to S. aureus, the larger the growth. This is termed satellitism. This occurs because factor V is released by the hemolytic action of S. aureus. 

The image below shows satellitism.

H. influenzae has a capsular polysaccharide which is a major antigenic determinant. Capsular typing is done to identify strains. Importantly, the type b capsular polysaccharide has a polyribosyl ribitol phosphate antigen (PRP). PRP is targeted during immunization. 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, laryngo-epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis. 

Cefotaxime or ceftazidime is the drug of choice for the treatment of Haemophilus meningitis. H. influenzae produces beta-lactamase, hence resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics like ampicillin.

H. influenza can be prevented by immunization with the Hib vaccine. The vaccine is produced based on the type b capsular polysaccharide. The capsule is composed of polyribosyl ribitol phosphate which can induce IgG, IgM, and IgA antibodies. Those that do not have a capsule are not candidates for vaccine prevention. Apart from H. influenza type b, the non-typeable strains are those that produce the clinical infections currently.

questions.text: An elderly man presenting with the features of urinary retention was thoroughly investigated and diagnosed with prostate carcinoma. All of the following statements about the Gleason system used for prognosis/survival of the patient are true except:

choices.text: Grade group 1 represents the most well-differentiated tumors.
Tumors with Gleason scores 8 to 10 tend to be advanced cancers.
Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.
Gleason Score is reported from 1 to 10.

questions.solution:
The Gleason score is currently reported from 6-10. 

WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score is the histopathological grading system, which corresponds with the clinical behavior of prostate cancer. It is one of the key methods used in confirmation of the diagnosis, prognostication, and staging of prostate cancer (adenocarcinoma). 

The Gleason grading system is primarily based on analyzing the architecture of the tumor cells in the biopsy specimens obtained. The architecture, i.e., the Gleason Patterns are classified as: 

    • Pattern 3: Well-formed glands
    • Pattern 4: Poorly formed/Fused/Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands
    • Pattern 5: Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords, and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis
    • Pattern 1 and 2 are no longer defined

Most tumor specimens contain more than one pattern. Therefore, a numeric grade is assigned to both the primary pattern and the next most frequent secondary pattern. The sum of the numeric grades provides the Gleason score.

  • Scores 2–5 are no longer assigned.
  • Scores of 6 - 7 are potentially treatable cancers
  • Scores 8 - 10 are advanced cancers that are less likely to be cured.

Based on the gleason score, they are classified into the following grade groups:

  • Grade group 1: score<=6
  • Grade group 2: 3+4=7
  • Grade group 3: 4+3=7
  • Grade group 4: score 8
  • Grade group 5: scores 9-10
