questions.text: A middle-aged male patient who has been diagnosed with short bowel syndrome is to be given parenteral nutrition. All of the following are true about the method of parenteral nutrition which can be seen in the image, except _____.

choices.text: This catheter has a mean survival duration of up to 7 days.
This is a method of central venous access.
This is inserted through peripheral veins of arm, but the tip of catheter is kept in superior vena cava.

questions.solution:
The method shown here is PICC-peripherally inserted central venous catheter. This is a method of Peripheral venous access.

Total parenteral nutrition can be provided by obtaining either peripheral venous access (up to 2 weeks) or central venous access. 

Peripheral venous access is achieved either by inserting a catheter into a peripheral vein and then maneuvering it into the central vein (peripherally inserted central venous catheter-PICC) or by a short wrist vein cannula. 

Central venous access is achieved by the subclavian, internal jugular, or external jugular vein. The infraclavicular subclavian approach is preferred as it is easier to provide nursing care. For long-term parenteral nutrition, Hickman lines are more appropriate.

The image below shows (A) a typical PICC line (B) the insertion of a PICC line (C) a patient with a PICC line inserted through the upper arm.

PICC lines:

  • This catheter has a mean survival duration of up to 7 days.
  • It can cause irreversible thrombophlebitis.
  • It minimizes inconvenience to the patient and clinician both.
  • This is inserted through the peripheral veins of arm, but the tip of catheter is kept in superior vena cava.

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia/hypoglycemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: A neonatologist prescribes the following method to practice to the family of a newborn child with 1.9 kg birth weight. What is incorrect regarding the positioning of the baby in this method?

choices.text: Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position.
The abdomen should be at the level of mother's epigastrium.
The legs should be extended and adducted.

questions.solution:
The image shows Kangaroo mother care (KMC), and the baby's legs must be flexed and abducted, not extended and adducted (Option D).

The Kangaroo positioning:

  • Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position. It keeps the airway of the baby open and allows eye-to-eye contact with the mother. 
  • The abdomen should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. The mother's breathing stimulates the baby, thus preventing apnea. 
  • The arms should be flexed.
  • The legs should be flexed and abducted in a 'frog' position. 

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components:

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

KMC can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC can even be done on mothers who are on IV fluids, CPAP, or even ventilators if they are hemodynamically stable.

Eligibiilty criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low-birth-weight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birthweight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
  • Birthweight 1200–1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birthweight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: In patients with Madelung deformity, where is the abnormality?

choices.text: Volar radial part of distal ulna
Volar ulnar part of distal radius
Dorsal ulnar part of distal radius
Dorsal radial part of distal ulna

questions.solution:
In Madelung deformity, there is an abnormality of the volar ulnar part of distal radius.

This is a congenital or post-traumatic deformity in children due to the disruption of the ulnar and volar aspect of the growth plate of the distal radius. This disruption is believed to be caused by the Vickers' ligament. This ligament normally tethers the lunate to the distal radius proximal to the physis, thus resulting in the dorsal and radial convexity of the radius.

Disruption of the growth plate causes a ventral curvature of the distal radius. However, the ulna continues to grow, and the distal ulna appears more prominent, making it stick out as a lump on the back of the wrist. This is known as a positive ulnar variance. There is volar subluxation of the hand.

Treatment consists of the conservative approach first, since the functional loss is minimal. Surgery is done when there is severe deformity or persistent pain.

questions.text: A school-going girl presents with jaundice and chronic fatigue. Examination revealed splenomegaly and conjunctival pallor. Blood tests show normocytic anemia, large spherical red blood cells without central pallor, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Her elder brother also has similar symptoms. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the gene coding for ankyrin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and splenomegaly is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. Ankyrin deficiency as well as family history points to the diagnosis as hereditary spherocytosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hereditary hemolytic anemia that is passed down in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations of the red blood cell surface proteins spectrin and ankyrin can result in unstable cell membranes, leading to hemolysis.

This disorder can present at a young age with severe jaundice and fatigue. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones. Hence, childhood gallstones should raise suspicion for this diagnosis.

Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test. 

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy. However, due to the possible adverse effects, it is only indicated in severe cases and after the child attains puberty in moderate cases. It should be followed up with the appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.

Other options:

Option (A): Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is a type of inherited hemolytic anemia. It is associated with exacerbations after consuming anti-malarial drugs and in periods of oxidative stress. It is not associated with ankyrin mutations. It is an X-linked disorder so it is unlikely to be seen in this patient.

Option (B): Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a hemolytic disorder that also presents with pancytopenia and a tendency to form venous thrombi. It occurs due to defective GPI anchors on the red blood cell surface which are normally used to anchor CD 59 (cell-protective proteins) to the surface. These patients can present with episodes of dark brown urine in the morning, anemia, pancytopenia, and recurrent abdominal pain due to thrombosis of abdominal veins.

Option (D): Hereditary elliptocytosis is also a type of inherited hemolytic anemia that results from spectrin and similar surface protein mutations. The clinical presentation is very similar to spherocytosis, but the peripheral smear will show elongated elliptical red blood cells instead of spherical ones.

questions.text:
A young man with a history of blunt abdominal trauma was brought to the emergency department. He was hemodynamically unstable, and a FAST examination revealed free fluid. An immediate laparotomy was done. The maneuver shown in the image below was performed due to severe bleeding near the liver. However, the bleeding continued. What could be the probable source of the bleeding in this case?

FAST - Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

choices.text: Both hepatic arterial and Portal venous bleeding

questions.solution:
The image shows clamping of the hepatoduodenal ligament, which is done in the Pringle maneuver. Bleeding that is not controlled by this maneuver suggests that the source of the bleeding is the hepatic vein. 

The Pringle manoeuvre is performed in surgery when there is excessive bleeding from the liver to temporarily arrest the bleeding and identify the source of the bleed, and is especially helpful in traumatic liver injury. With the occlusion of the portal triad, the inflow from the hepatic artery and portal vein are controlled, but backflow from the IVC and hepatic vein persists. After performing this maneuver, the liver laceration can be explored, and further bleeding can be controlled.

It is one of the 4 Ps in the management of liver injuries, which include: 

  • Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration
  • Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad
  • Plug- The defects are plugged with silicon tubes
  • Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding

Ischemia and portal hypertension are complications that result from either prolonged clamping time during the Pringle maneuver or normal clamping time in patients with compromised liver function (eg, from cirrhosis).

A patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and oliguria for 3 days. On examination, swelling around the eyes and both ankles was noted. The results of his laboratory investigations are given below. What is the most likely cause?

Fractional excretion of sodium(FeNa): 0.5%

Urine osmolality: 600mOsm/kg
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with nausea, vomiting, oliguria, and swelling around the eyes and ankles along with laboratory values of FeNa and Urine osmolality suggests prerenal acute kidney injury an example of which is cardiac failure.

  • BUN/creatinine ratio above 20

questions.text: What is the location of the complexes shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the electron transport chain (ETC) which is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane. 

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons. Energy-rich molecules like glucose are oxidized to produce water and carbon dioxide. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes like nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2). The reduced forms can then donate electrons to the ETC by which they lose most of their free energy which is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation. 

Option B - Outer mitochondrial membrane has acyl-CoA synthetase and glycerol phosphate acyltransferase.

Option C - Mitochondrial matrix has citric acid cycle enzymes, β-oxidation enzymes, and pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Option D - Intermembrane space has adenylyl kinase and creatine kinase.

questions.text: A patient with chronic dacryocystitis, refractory to the medical treatment, has been scheduled for dacryocystorhinostomy. Following the surgery, the sac would be draining into the _______.
questions.solution:
After dacryocystorhinostomy, the lacrimal sac drains into the middle meatus.

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus. 

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CONS) and Staphylococcus aureus are the organisms responsible for the majority of chronic dacrocystitis cases. Chronic dacryocystitis can be treated with amoxyclav and third-generation cephalosporins.

questions.text: A 63-year-old diabetic patient is diagnosed with hypertension. Urine examination reveals microalbuminuria. Which antihypertensive would be preferred in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In an elderly diabetic patient with hypertension and proteinuria, the preferred antihypertensive is captopril, which is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.

Drugs interfering with the renin-angiotensin mechanism like ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are the first-line antihypertensives in diabetic patients with hypertension. These drugs provide a renoprotective effect.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old child presented with the deformity shown in the image. Subsequent investigations revealed a mutation in the PHEX gene and increased levels of fibroblast growth factor-23 (FGF 23). Which of the following is the likely set of reports for the patient?
  S. phosphate S. Calcium  S. PTH pH
1 Low Normal High Low
2 High Low High Normal
3 Low Low High Normal
4 Low Normal Normal Normal
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing the wind-swept deformity (characteristic of rickets in a pediatric patient) and PHEX gene mutation is suggestive of X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets. This patient's laboratory reports will show low phosphate levels, normal calcium levels, parathyroid hormone levels, and normal pH. 

Hypophosphatemic rickets:

X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common genetic cause of rickets. PHEX gene (phosphate-regulating endopeptidase on x chromosome) products are responsible for the inactivation of phosphatonin. Mutation of this PHEX leads to increased phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels, and hence, the excretion of phosphorous is increased. This is impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate.

Other causes of hypophosphatemic rickets include:

  • Autosomal dominant hypophosphatemic rickets
  • Autosomal recessive hypophosphatemic rickets
  • Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria
  • Tumor-induced rickets
  • Fanconi Syndrome

The chart attached below summarizes the evaluation of hypophosphatemic rickets:


Patients respond well to a combination of oral phosphorus and 1,25-D (calcitriol). The daily need for phosphorus supplementation is 1–3 g of elemental phosphorus divided into 4–5 doses. Frequent dosing helps prevent prolonged decrements in serum phosphorus levels because there is a rapid decline after each dose. In addition, frequent dosing decreases diarrhea, which is a complication of high-dose oral phosphorus. Calcitriol is administered 30–70 ng/kg/day divided into 2 doses. 

Further, Joulie's solution is also useful in the treatment of familial hypophosphatemic rickets. Joulie's solution includes contains 30.4 mg of phosphate/mL. The most common side effect is diarrhea. 

Other options:

Option A is seen in proximal renal tubular acidosis (Type 2 RTA). Serum phosphate is low due to phosphate wasting, serum calcium is usually normal, serum PTH is elevated due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, and urine pH is initially acidic but may become less acidic as bicarbonate loss worsens, resulting in metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Option B can be seen in rickets associated with chronic renal failure. Serum phosphate levels are typically elevated due to impaired renal excretion. Serum calcium levels may be low or normal because the kidneys are unable to produce sufficient active vitamin D, leading to impaired calcium absorption and phosphate retention. Serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are elevated due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which occurs as a compensatory response to low calcium and high phosphate and pH levels in the blood may be normal or low, reflecting the presence of metabolic acidosis often associated with reduced kidney function.

Option C shows the set of reports in the case of nutritional rickets. It commonly occurs due to the deficiency of vitamin D, thereby affecting the metabolism of calcium and phosphate ions in the body. In vitamin D deficiency, low calcium levels may be seen in the blood. To raise serum calcium levels, the secretion of the parathyroid hormone (PTH) rises. 

Related Pearl: Vitamin D activation and Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was admitted for evaluation of fever. However, there were inconsistencies in the mother's reporting of medical information. Further exploration revealed that she had taken her child to multiple hospitals giving varying histories of lupus, asthma, etc that prompted excessive testing. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the inaccurate histories given by the mother to prompt excessive testing on the child, point towards a diagnosis of factitious disorder by proxy (DSM-5 diagnosis of "Factitious Disorder Imposed on Another").

The most common case of factitious disorder by proxy involves a mother who deceives medical personnel into believing that her child is ill. Here, the affected person intentionally produces physical signs or symptoms in another person who is under his own care. One apparent purpose of the behavior is for the caretaker to indirectly assume the sick role.

questions.text: An infant demonstrates lethargy, vomiting, and convulsions after a few sessions of breastfeeding. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ammonia. It is found that the infant has a defect in an enzyme activated by N-acetyl glutamate. Identify the enzyme.
questions.solution:
N-acetyl glutamate is an allosteric activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I). CPS I catalyzes the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle and is present in the mitochondria. This reaction uses up two molecules of ATP to generate one molecule of carbamoyl phosphate. Its defect leads to hyperammonemia type 1.

The clinical symptoms of urea cycle disorders include vomiting, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, severe mental retardation, hypothermia, and apnea due to high plasma ammonia levels.

Option A: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is the rate-limiting enzyme in pyrimidine synthesis. It is inhibited by UTP (uridine triphosphate) and activated by ATP and PRPP (phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate).

CPS I  CPS II
Rate-limiting enzyme of urea cycle Rate limiting step of pyrimidine synthesis
Found in mitochondria Found in cytosol
Uses ammonia as a source of nitrogen Uses glutamine as a source of nitrogen
Requires N-acetyl glutamate as a positive allosteric activator Does not require N-acetyl glutamate

Option C: Ornithine transcarbamoylase combines carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. Deficiency causes elevated glutamine levels in the blood, CSF, and urine.

Option D: Argininosuccinate synthetase leads to the synthesis of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the primary health center with a history of snakebite. The area of the bite is painful and appears red and swollen. From his description, the snake that bit him had a triangular head with a V-shaped mark, as shown in the image below. All of the following statements regarding this snake bite are true, except ___.

choices.text: Death is due to shock and hemorrhage
Persistent bleeding from bite site is noticed
Bleeding and clotting time are prolonged

questions.solution:
From the patient's description and the image, the snake is most likely Russell's viper. The victims of Russell's viper may become oliguric within a few hours of the bite suggesting renal ischemia.

The Russell's viper has a flat and triangular head with a V-shaped mark, white in color, with the angle of the V pointing forwards. Along the back, it has three rows of diamond-shaped spots. Other points of identification include broad plates on its belly, the small scales on the head, and a shield beneath the tail divided into two rows. It is commonly found throughout India.

Russell's viper venom contains two proteases that affect the blood-clotting cascade. Though more than half the victims have minimal or no poisoning, few develop serious generalized poisoning. At the spot where venom is injected, the patient develops severe pain and the area around the bite becomes red and painful. Persistent bleeding from the bite site is a constant feature. Blisters begin to appear in some hours which progressively involves the entire limb. Skin temperature is raised. Intravascular hemolysis may lead to hemoglobinuria which progresses to renal failure.

Since the venom affects the blood-clotting cascade, the bleeding and clotting time are usually prolonged. Patients may develop hemorrhagic syndrome due to bleeding from various sites like gums, rectum, etc. Death is usually due to hemorrhagic shock.

questions.text: A patient presents with claudication in the right thigh during walking. There is no history of impotence or buttock claudication. On examination, the right femoral and distal pulses are absent. Angiography is given below. What will be the best surgical management?
questions.solution:
The symptom of pain in the right thigh while walking and the given angiography findings are suggestive of aortoiliac occlusive disease with right common iliac artery obstruction. The treatment of choice for unilateral iliac vessel occlusion is an aortofemoral bypass.

Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases.

Diagnosis of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases includes:

  • Clinical examination- weakened pulses below the level of obstruction
  • Reduced Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) -<0.9 - intermittent claudication (occlusive arterial disease)<0.3 - critical limb ischemia.
  • Color doppler- normal artery has a triphasic signal
    • Biphasic waveform - mild-moderate stenosis
    • Monophasic waveform - severe stenosis
  • Duplex scanning - a non-invasive technique that uses a combination of B-mode ultrasound and Doppler study. 
  • Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is now the standard technique. The artery is better outlined because the photos are digitized by a computer, which removes extraneous tissues.
  • CT angiography (CTA) and MR angiography (MRA) - for extent and type of obstruction. These are not used routinely for the diagnosis but only if symptoms warrant surgical intervention.

Below is an angiography image showing the right common iliac artery obstruction.

Management of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases is as follows:

  • Carbohydrate and lipid-free diet
  • Graduated exercise program in combination with smoking cessation improves walking efficiency
  • Control of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia
  • Percutaneous transluminal balloon angioplasty (PTA) - is more useful for isolated iliac stenosis (<4cm in length) rather than occlusion
  • Bypass graft surgeries 

The site of obstruction, the clinical findings, and recommended bypass graft surgeries are tabulated below:

Site of disease Clinical findings Surgical reconstruction
Aortoiliac obstruction (at the aortic bifurcation)
  • Buttock claudication  (may also occur in thigh and calves)
  • Impotence (Leriche syndrome)
  • Absence of femoral and distal pulses in both limbs.
  • Bruit over the aortoiliac region
  • Anatomical reconstruction
  • Aortobifemoral bypass - gold-standard 
  • Aortoiliac endarterectomy/Aortoiliac bypass - rarely performed; associated with greater blood loss and sexual dysfunction
  • Extra-anatomical reconstruction 
  • Axillo-bifemoral bypass - only in medically unfit patients
Iliac obstruction
  • Unilateral claudication in the thigh and calf (and sometimes the buttock)
  • Unilateral absence of femoral and distal pulses
  • Bruit over the iliac region 
  • Aortofemoral bypass - gold-standard 
  • Iliofemoral bypass - can be done for unilateral occlusion of the distal common iliac or external iliac artery; preferred over femorofemoral bypass for medically fit patients.
  • Femorofemoral bypass - can be done for unilateral stenosis or occlusion of the common or external iliac artery (only in medically unfit patients)
Femoropopliteal obstruction
  • Unilateral claudication in the calf
  • Femoral pulse palpable with an absence of unilateral distal pulses
 Femoropopliteal bypass - ideal procedure if popliteal artery below the knee is patent
Infrapopliteal bypass - if the disease involves popliteal or proximal tibial artery

A collagen-impregnated, knitted Dacron graft is used for proximal aortic anastomosis in aortofemoral bypass. For femoropopliteal bypass grafting, a great saphenous vein graft is ideal.

questions.text: Tizanidine is a drug used for the treatment of spasticity in multiple sclerosis. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Tizanidine is a α2 adrenergic receptor agonist.

Tizanidine is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. It is used to treat spasticity in multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or after stroke. Treatment is started with a low dose and gradually tilted upwards. Side effects include dry mouth, drowsiness, insomnia, and hallucinations.

Other options:

Option A: Nm receptor antagonism is the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants. The drugs in this class include pancuronium, vecuronium, rocuronium, atracurium, mivacurium, etc.

Option C: D2 receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of bromocriptine. It is used for the treatment of prolactinoma and Parkinson's disease.

Option D: GABA B receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of baclofen. It is used for the same purpose as tizanidine, a centrally-acting muscle relaxant.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with conductive hearing loss, palatal asymmetry, and facial pain. He also has painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Which part of the trigeminal nerve is involved in the triad seen in this condition?

choices.text: V3- Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve
V2- Maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve
V1- Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Trotter’s triad or sinus of Morgagni syndrome seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It involves V3- Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.

Trotter’s triad consists of:

  • Conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube obstruction
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain
  • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of the vagus nerve (CN X) which presents as palatal asymmetry

questions.text: A 38-year-old multigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presented to the outpatient department with a history of painless vaginal bleeding. On examination, there is a fall in fetal heart rate when the fetal head is pushed into the pelvis. Identify the true statement about the condition associated with the sign described.

choices.text: Transabdominal sonography is the most accurate method of assessment.
MR imaging has replaced sonography in diagnosis.
Per vaginal examination should be avoided.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of painless vaginal bleeding with positive Stallworthy's sign is suggestive of placenta previa and the true statement associated with it is per vaginal examination should be avoided, as it can lead to torrential hemorrhage.

Stallworthy's sign refers to the slowing of the fetal heart rate when the head is pressed down into the pelvis. It recovers as soon as the pressure is released. It is suggestive of the presence of a low-lying placenta, particularly if located on the posterior wall of the uterus. 

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. 

Common risk factors for placenta previa include

  • Previous cesarian section
  • Myomectomy
  • Advanced maternal age (>35 years)
  • Smoking
  • multiple gestation
  • Multiparity
  • Prior curettage

Diagnosis :

  • Transabdominal sonography: A quick and accurate localization can be accomplished if the placenta clearly overlies the cervix or if it lies away from the lower uterine segment. Its limitations include:
    • Poor visualization in obese women
    • A full bladder may give a false impression that the placenta is overlying the cervix.
  • Transvaginal sonography: The most accurate method to assess the placental location. It is not contraindicated in placenta previa and is safe even when there is bleeding.
  • MRI: Localizes placental location excellently, gold standard but does not replace sonography in routine diagnosis.
  • In case of inconclusive USG reports or USG revealed type 1 placenta, a vaginal examination is done in operation theatre under anesthesia. This is done with preparation for an immediate cesarean section. 

There are four types of placenta previa depending upon the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment.

  • Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

Note: For clinical purpose, the types are graded into,

  • Mild degree (Type-I and II anterior) and
  • Major degree (Type-II posterior, III, and IV).

questions.text: For years, a gold standard test (green curves) is being used for the diagnosis of the disease. Recently, a new test (purple curves) has been discovered and the researcher claims it to be a better test. Compared to the gold standard test, the new test has:
questions.solution:
The new test (purple curves) has higher sensitivity and higher specificity.

In the new test (purple curves), both false positives (FP) and false negatives (FN) have reduced.  

Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN)

  • Sensitivity is inversely related to FN.
  • Therefore, reducing FN would increase the sensitivity.

Specificity = TN/(TN + FP)

  • Specificity is inversely related to FP.
  • Therefore, reducing FP would increase the specificity.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with complaints of headache, eye pain, and frequent change of glasses over the past few months. An eye examination was performed after dilating the pupil and it showed the following finding. Her intraocular pressure was raised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on clinical features and the image given is pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related degenerative disorder, more commonly seen in elderly women. The pathogenesis involves the deposition of a grey-white fibrillary substance derived from abnormal extracellular matrix metabolism in ocular and other tissues.

The deposition of this exfoliative material occurs on the iris, ciliary region, and lens capsule. They appear as flakes on the anterior lens capsule and edge of the iris. There is radially indented peripheral layer of pseudoexfoliative material, separated by a clear zone maintained by pupillary abrasion (figure shows this). Pupillary dilation helps in visualizing this peripheral capsular deposition.

The material can get collected in the anterior chamber angle and impede the aqueous humor drainage, thus developing open-angle glaucoma. Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen. Gonioscopy may show these deposits.

Treatment involves laser trabeculoplasty to remove this material deposition.

Other options

Option A: Traumatic glaucoma will be associated with hyphema or ciliary body rupture leading to angle recession. The above does not correspond to either of them.

Option B: Posner–Schlossman syndrome is characterized by recurrent attacks of unilateral acute raised IOP associated with mild anterior uveitis. Males are more commonly affected than females.

Option C: Pigmentary glaucoma is common in young myopic males. Here the iris rubs against zonules posteriorly resulting in pigment dispersion causing blockadge of trabecular meshwork. It will be associated with iris tramsillumination defect and pigment deposits on the anterior lens, margins of iris etc.

questions.text: A young woman visits the doctor because she has stiffness in her wrist and small joints of the hand. It is more in the early morning and improves with physical activity. On examination, swelling and pain are noted in the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, and proximal interphalangeal joints. Laboratory investigations reveal high titers of anti-CCP antibodies. Which of the following is the most common pulmonary manifestation of this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The most common pulmonary manifestation of this disease is Pleuritis. Clinical features of rheumatoid arthritis:

Joints: Patients have early morning stiffness of joints of the hand. This stiffness persists for around 1 hour and improves with physical activity. The most commonly involved joints are wrists, metacarpophalangeal (MCP), and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Chronic progressive destruction of the joint leads to deformities.

  • Ulnar deviation: Results from subluxation of the MCP joints, with subluxation, or partial dislocation, of the proximal phalanx to the volar side of the hand.
  • Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. 
  • Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint
  • Z-line deformity: Subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint

Extra-articular features:

Skin: Firm and non-tender nodules that are adherent to the periosteum, tendons, or bursae

Pulmonary: Pleuritis is the most common pulmonary manifestation seen in Rheumatoid arthritis. Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP), a type of ILD is seen more commonly in males and smokers.

Cardiac: It can cause pericarditis, cardiomyopathy, mitral regurgitation, etc.

Rheumatoid:vasculitis presents as petechiae, purpura, digital infarcts, gangrene, livedo reticularis

Hematological: Normochromic normocytic anemia

Rheumatoid arthritis disease is commonly associated with coronary artery disease, carotid atherosclerosis, osteoporosis, and hypoandrogenism. 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis. 

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text:
Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for a country is best given as:

MMR = (No. of maternal deaths in a given year/ Total no. of live births in the same year) x 100,000
Death of which mothers in the list given below would you include in the numerator?

  1. Death of a 26-year-old primigravida during 3rd trimester due to electric shock
  2. Death of a 33-year-old multigravida during labor due to blood loss of 1.5 L 
  3. Death of a 29-year-old female after 1 month of normal vaginal delivery due to sepsis induced by endometritis
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C-2, 3.

The maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.

Maternal death is defined as

  • Death of a woman while pregnant.
  • Death during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

MMR = (No. of maternal deaths in a given year/ Total no. of live births in the same year) x 100,000

In a developing country like India, maternal mortality is a huge public health issue. The most common causes are postpartum hemorrhage and infections. This mainly occurs because women do not give birth in hospitals or health centers.

The main contributor to a decline in maternal mortality has been attributed to a rise in institutional deliveries.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was incidentally noted to have elevated calcium levels. Further evaluation revealed that he has increased levels of PTH.  He is otherwise completely asymptomatic. A diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism is made. Which of the following is not an indication for parathyroidectomy in this patient?

choices.text: Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limits of normal

questions.solution:
Creatinine clearance <60 mL/min is an indication of parathyroidectomy in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Asymptomatic Primary Hyperparathyroidism -

Incidental findings of hypercalcemia during biochemical screening tests account for 80% of cases. In asymptomatic hyperparathyroidism, the mean serum calcium concentration is less than 1.0 mg/dL above the upper limit of the normal range. At the National Institutes of Health consensus conference, “asymptomatic” PHPT was defined as “the absence of common symptoms and signs of PHPT, including no bone, renal, gastrointestinal, or neuromuscular disorders.” 

Medical management involves the use of bisphosphonates and selective estrogen receptor modulators. 

Related Pearl: Indications for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary HPT (2013-2014 NIH Consensus Conference Guidelines)

  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal
  • Renal: 
    • Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30%
    • 24-h urine calcium >400 mg/day
    • Presence of nephrolithiasis or nephrocalcinosis
  • Skeletal: 
    • Decreased bone mineral density (T score <-2.5)
    • Presence of vertebral fracture
  • Age <50 years

questions.text: What is the type of Salter-Harris physeal injury shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a fracture line through the growth plate and the metaphysis of the lower end of bone, sparing the epiphysis; this suggests Salter-Harris type II injury.

In a type II fracture, the fracture lies away from the joint. The fracture involves the physis and a triangle of metaphyseal bone (Thurston Holland sign). This type is the commonest type of epiphyseal injury in patients over 10 years of age.

Salter-Harris classified epiphyseal injuries into 5 types. Rang added the sixth type, in which there is a peripheral physis lesion.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A G2P1 woman at 39 weeks of gestation with a history of classical cesarean section is admitted for delivery. During the second stage of labor, she is noted to have fetal bradycardia associated with some vaginal bleeding. On per vaginal examination, the fetal station which was previously at +2, is at -3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on clinical features such as bleeding, loss of fetal station, and fetal bradycardia is uterine rupture.

Uterine rupture is when all the layers of the uterus (endometrium, myometrium, and serosa) are disrupted at any time after 28 weeks of pregnancy.

A previous history of classical cesarean section, obstructed labour, manual removal of placenta, dilatation and curettage are some risk factors for uterine scar rupture.

Clinical features:

  • Maternal tachycardia
  • Fetal bradycardia
  • Maternal hypotension
  • Uterine scar tenderness
  • Bleeding per vagina
  • Hematuria 
  • Loss of station of presenting part

Management of uterine scar rupture includes resuscitation and laparotomy. Following resuscitative measures and laparotomy, subtotal hysterectomy is usually done unless there is sufficient reason to preserve the uterus.

Note: "Loss of fetal station" is used to describe a situation where the fetal head, which has previously descended into the pelvic cavity during labour, begins to move back up during labour. This can be indicative of issues such as fetal malposition, cephalopelvic disproportion, or obstructed labour.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoma of the tongue has a defect of more than 2 cm.  The patient is planned for hemiglossectomy and tongue reconstruction using a radial forearm flap. The surgeon plans to use the following approach. What is this procedure/ approach called?
questions.solution:
The picture shows the visor approach (like the visor of the helmet). It provides excellent access to the floor of the mouth and tongue. 

In the Visor approach, an incision is made in the cervical crease from the mastoid to the mastoid. Another incision is made in the lingual gingival sulcus from one posterior molar to the other side posterior molar. This frees the skin which is present over the chin and floor of the mouth. This flap is elevated like a visor of the helmet providing a wide exposure to remove larger lesions involving the anterior oral cavity that is not amenable to a peroral approach. This avoids a lip-splitting incision but has the disadvantage of anesthesia of chin/lower lip (due to the sacrifice of submental nerves).

The lip-split (Option A) and paramedian/ median mandibulotomy approaches are used for the treatment of oropharyngeal cancers. Lip-split mandibulotomy is the most commonly used access procedure. It provides better access to posterior oral cavity, base of tongue, and oropharynx.

Trans-oral wedge resection (Option C) is done for moderate-sized anterior oral tumors.

Commando operation (Option D) is combined mandibular resection and neck node dissection, and it is used mainly for carcinoma of the tongue.

questions.text: A patient with burns was planned for skin reconstruction using the graft technique shown in the image below. What are the layers of skin included while harvesting this graft?
questions.solution:
The image given depicts the harvesting of a split skin graft. Epidermis + part of dermis are included here.

The donor site cannot be reused before healing. The most preferable donor site is the buttocks in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or electric dermatome.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is contraindicated in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donor to full-thickness defect.

Skin grafts can be broadly divided into two categories:

Split-thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts. Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. More dermis in the full-thickness skin graft translates into more primary contraction and less secondary contraction.

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft takeup. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post-graft contraction.
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with shortness of breath associated with wheezing. In case of aspirin hypersensitivity, which of the following mediators will be responsible for the above  condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has aspirin-induced asthma and it is due to the formation of leukotrienes.

Aspirin causes inhibition of cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1), which would inhibit the formation of thromboxane A2. Inhibition of the COX pathway also leads to the overproduction of leukotrienes since the products are diverted towards the lipooxygenase pathway, which is not inhibited by aspirin.

Apart from this, prostacyclin and PGE2 are also produced via the COX pathway and thus this would decrease by aspirin.

Treatment of aspirin-induced asthma includes leukotriene modifiers and aspirin desensitization.

Aspirin is a non-competitive, irreversible inhibitor of the COX enzyme. It is a nonselective COX inhibitor and inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. 

Adverse effects:

Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and is a potent vasoconstrictor. Hence inhibition of its formation is responsible for the bleeding complications of aspirin.

Nausea, vomiting, epigastric discomfort, and increased occult blood in stools are seen with analgesic doses(0.5–2 g/day). Antiinflammatory doses (3–5 g/day) can produce salicylism characterized by dizziness, tinnitus, vertigo, hyperventilation, reversible loss of hearing and vision, etc. It can cause elevation of liver enzymes and hepatic damage. Hypersensitivity reactions are also seen.

Reye's syndrome is a rare condition that can occur when salicylates like aspirin are given in children having viral infections like influenza.

questions.text: A young man presents with a history of head injury. On examination, his pulse rate is 52/minute, blood pressure is 168/100 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 10/min. Which among the following options is responsible for the raised blood pressure in this patient?
questions.solution:
The reflex responsible for elevated BP in a patient with a head injury is the Cushing reflex. The Cushing reflex is a triad of:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea).

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised. This leads to local hypoxia and hypercapnia which in turn increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors located on the ventrolateral medullary surface. This activation causes a rise in blood pressure which then restores the blood flow to the medulla. However, the arterial baroreceptors sense this increase in the systemic blood pressure and cause a reflex decrease in the heart rate. 

Other options-

Option A: J Reflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which causes a reflex increase in respiratory rate and dyspnea. 

Option B: Bainbridge reflex is the reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Option C: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery). This is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: The pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) that does not spread through the sexual route is _____.
questions.solution:
The only PID that does not spread through the sexual route is genital TB. It has a hematogenous spread. Very rarely, it can have a lymphatic or direct transperitoneal spread. Therefore, in genital TB, involvement of the fallopian tubes is always bilateral.

PID is a polymicrobial infection.

  • The only PID that does not spread with the sexual route is genital TB. It has a hematogenous spread.
  • Most common PID in virgin females is genital TB.
  • Investigation of choice in PID: Abdominal USG
  • Surest sign of salpingitis is pus extruding from the fimbrial end of the tube.

questions.text: A woman with a negative urine pregnancy test presents to you with galactorrhea. She is taking metoprolol for blood pressure control. Her prolactin levels are 35 mcg/L, and TSH and free T4 levels are reduced. What is the most likely cause for her elevated prolactin levels?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for her elevated prolactin levels is pituitary stalk compression.

Dopamine is a prolactin-release inhibitory factor, and disruption of the pituitary stalk leads to impaired transport of dopamine to lactotrophs and, thus, loss of inhibition. This leads to an increase in prolactin levels.

This diagnosis is also supported by the fact that there is also secondary hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH and free T4. This is because TRH stimulates TSH secretion from the pituitary. Loss of stalk function will lead to reduced influence of TRH on TSH.

Other options:

Option B: Prolactinoma is generally diagnosed at prolactin levels of >200 mcg/L.

Option C: Primary hypothyroidism would have increased TSH along with a decrease in free T4 levels.

Option D: Metoprolol does not affect prolactin levels.

questions.text: A primigravida woman gives birth to a baby with the following defect; the baby later died from the complications of the defect. What would have been the likely pathogenesis for this malformation?

choices.text: Defective vertebral column with meninges protruding out
Failure of complete closure of the neural tube
Defective vertebral column with meninges and spinal cord  protruding out
Partial closure of the neural tube

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing anencephaly and a contiguous bony defect of the spine, is suggestive of craniorachischisis. It occurs due to failure of complete closure of the neural tube.

Rachischisis is the most severe type of neural tube defect, where the entire neural tube fails to close. Rachischisis can occur in the spinal cord or brain regions of the neural tube. The exposed neural tissues often become necrotic. 

The image given below shows craniorachischisis.

Spina bifida is a general term used for neural tube defects affecting the spinal region and associated with splitting of the vertebral arches. It is characterized by gaps in the vertebral arches and may or may not involve the underlying neural tissue.

The illustration shown below shows spina bifida.

The 3 main types of spina bifida:

  • Spina bifida occulta - This is the mildest form of spina bifida. The defect in the vertebral arches is covered by the skin. The splits in the vertebrae are so small that the spinal cord does not protrude. The skin at the site of the lesion may be normal, or it may have some hair growing from it.
  • Meningocele - The defect in the vertebra allows the meninges to protrude through the defect.
  • Myelomeningocele (meningomyelocele) - Defect in the vertebral column allows the spinal cord with the meningeal coverings to protrude. 

The image given below shows the different types of spina bifida.

questions.text:
All of the following cause a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, except ___.

HbF- Fetal hemoglobin

2,3 BPG- 2,3 Bisphosphoglyceric acid
questions.solution:
Increased HbF (fetal hemoglobin) causes a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve. 

Oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve:

This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the percentage saturation of Hb with O2. It is normally sigmoid in shape. If the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less, which favors O2 delivery. This means a higher P50, which implies that a higher PO2 is required to maintain 50% saturation (R - Right shift Releases oxygen). If the curve is shifted to the left, it means that affinity has increased for O2 ( which favors O2 binding ) i.e. lower P50 value ( L-Left shift Leashes oxygen ).

Causes of the right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve:

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anemia - reduced affinity for O2
  • Exercise

Causes of the left shift of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve:

  • ↑ pH (alkalosis)
  • ↓ PCO2
  • ↓ 2,3-DPG
  • ↓ Temperature 
  • HbF
  • Carboxyhemoglobin

Bohr's effect- The decrease in the O2 affinity of hemoglobin when the pH of the blood falls

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have an intracardiac thrombus and was scheduled for a transesophageal echocardiography. Which chamber of the heart is closest to the probe during this procedure?
questions.solution:
The left atrium is closest to the esophagus, separated only by the pericardium. Hence, it would be the chamber closest to the transesophageal probe.

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the test of choice for prosthetic valve vegetation, intracardiac thrombi, and left atrial appendage.

Since TEE has to penetrate fewer structures (chest wall, ribs, etc.), a higher frequency probe can be used, giving better resolution images than transthoracic echocardiography.

questions.text: A newborn was found to have a following anomaly of the penile urethra while being examined by a pediatrician. Identify the incorrect statement regarding the condition.

choices.text: It is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra
Circumcision should be done to remove the excess skin
It does not cause urinary obstruction
Ventral chordee is a common association

questions.solution:
The image showing a newborn having a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penis is indicative of hypospadias. Circumcision should not be done in hypospadias as the foreskin will be used for surgical reconstruction.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by the combination of:

  • A ventrally placed urethral meatus (underside of penis or perineum)
  • Poor development of the ventral aspect of the prepuce (resulting in hooded foreskin)
  • Ventral chordee (bending of the penis)

Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection and surgery is recommended for sexual, urinary stream, or cosmetic reasons. 

Note: In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with a history of frequent infections, fatigue, headaches and blurring of vision. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests show normocytic normochromic anemia and a positive Coombs test, with serum electrophoresis revealing a sharp spike of monoclonal IgM. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has classic symptoms due to hyperviscosity, like headache and blurring of vision, and has a spike of monoclonal IgM. The most likely diagnosis is Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia.

Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia is a plasma cell disorder that results in increased proliferation of memory B cells. These cells produce large amounts of IgM, leading to the classic hyperviscosity syndrome. 

Patients present with anaemia, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hyperviscosity, or peripheral neuropathy. Most commonly, they present with fatigue, weakness, and oozing of blood from the nasal or oral cavity. 

Haematological examination reveals Coombs’ positive test and rouleaux formation. This condition also has a greater incidence of normocytic normochromic anaemia.

The hyperviscosity state can be treated by plasmapheresis. However, most patients do not require therapy unless they are symptomatic (anaemia, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly.) It can be treated with ibrutinib, which targets the activated BTK mutation. Rituximab with cyclophosphamide can also be used. 

Option A - Hodgkin’s lymphoma is a condition that results in the proliferation of mature B lymphocytes. It is characterised by night sweats, fever, fatigue, and painless supraclavicular and axillary lymphadenopathy. There are no hyperviscosity symptoms or hepatosplenomegaly. 

Option B - Multiple myeloma and Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia are similar in course as they are both plasma cell disorders. However, there are several key differences between the two. Lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal failure, which are more suggestive of myeloma, are not seen in this patient. Also, multiple myeloma has a spike of IgG in the majority of the cases.

Option D - Amyloidosis involves the extracellular deposition of fibrillary proteins. There is usually multiorgan involvement, most commonly leading to renal, splenic, and cardiac disease. The IgM spike that is present in this patient would not be seen in amyloidosis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the respiratory medicine department with an illness resembling tuberculosis. Further investigations confirmed that it is an infection with non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM). Identify the incorrect statement regarding NTM.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college-going student presents to you with a rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. She has a history of persistent eye rubbing. You also noticed the following sign, when the patient was asked to look in a downward gaze. All the following are treatment options for given condition except?

choices.text: Riboflavin drops, followed by exposure to UV-B radiation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and lower lid bulging on downgaze (Munson's sign- as shown in the image) is suggestive of keratoconus. Riboflavin drops, followed by exposure to UV-A radiation (not UV-B), is a treatment modality for this condition.

Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often cause significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

Important associations:

  • Rigid contact lens wear
  • Chronic eye rubbing
  • Marfan's, Down’s, EDS syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta, MVP
  • RP, Leber congenital amaurosis
  • VKC, aniridia, ectopia lentis

Investigations:

  • Corneal topography
  • Pachymetry
  • Keratometry:
    • Steep cornea
    • Bow tie pattern
    • Paracentral thinning of the cornea (thinnest point) 

Treatment:

  • Spectacle correction
  • Rigid gas-permeable contact lens
  • Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) - instillation of riboflavin drops to photosensitize the eye, followed by exposure to ultraviolet-A light
  • Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that are implanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature in an effort to improve vision
  • Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetrating keratoplasty (PKP)

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man from Madhya Pradesh presented with gradual-onset spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Upon inquiry, he mentions that he has a similar family history. Suspecting a poisoning by consumption of a local dal 'Batra', you recommend him to take the following measure to remove the toxin, in order to prevent such an occurrence in the future:

Soak the dal in lime water overnight, followed by boiling. It removes not only the toxin, but also destroys trypsin inhibitors. 

What is this technique called?
questions.solution:
This technique is called 'parboiling'. The case described here is that of lathyrism. 

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. (Local names: teora dhal, lak dhal, batra, gharas, matra, etc.). When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram dal or Bengal gram dal. It is more prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. In animals, it is referred to as osteolathyrism/odoratism because the pathological changes in the bones lead to skeletal deformities. It usually affects young males aged 15–45 years, and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing lathyrism. 

Vitamin C in doses of 500–1000 mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism. The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/split/flour).

Methods to remove toxin:

  • Steeping method: The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water.  
  • Parboiling can be used for detoxifying the crop on large-scale operations. Overnight soaking in lime water, followed by boiling, is also effective in destroying the toxin. 
  • Public Education
  • Genetic approach: Selective cultivation and propagation of certain strains of Lathyrus, which contain very low levels of toxin (0.1%).
  • Socio-economic changes
