questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9×10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of Phyllodes tumor or cystosarcoma phyllodes of the breast.

Phyllodes tumor, also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition.

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes or as serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some of the low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors, and malignant type- Mastectomy

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor.

 

Other options:

Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign solid encapsulated tumors. It is a slow-growing tumor and presents as a painless lump in the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory cancer is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics. Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a history revealing the rapid onset of the disease with progression over weeks to 3 months.

The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: According to the non-rural housing standards in India, which is incorrect?

choices.text: Height of roof should not be less than 10 feet.
Every house must have a sanitary privy.
A pucca floor that is impermeable, easy to clean, free from cracks should be there.
Site should be at the level of the ground.

questions.solution:
Site should be elevated above the level of the ground to protect from rains and floods.

Non-Rural Housing Standards in India:

Housing parameters

Description
Site

Elevated to protect from rains and floods.

Independent access to the street.

Away from vector breeding sites and other pollutants like smoke, noise, dust.

The soil on which it is founded must be dry and safe.
Floor A pucca floor that is impermeable, easy to clean, free from cracks, damp-proof. The height of the plinth must be 2 – 3 feet.
Walls 9 inch thick, strong, low heat capacity, weather-resistant, unsuitable for harbourage of rats/vermin.
Roof Height not less than 10 feet (3m).
Rooms The number of rooms must be according to the size of the family but the basic number is two.
Floor area A living room should have at least 120 sq. ft. of area for occupancy of more than 1 person and 100 sq. ft. for occupancy of only one person. 50 -100 sq. ft. floor area per person is optimum in a living room.
Cubic space 500 – 1000 cubic feet of air space per capita.
Windows At least 2 windows per room with one opening into an open space. Windows must be at a height of not more than 3 feet above the ground. The window area must be 1/5th of the floor area.
Lighting The daylight factor should be >1% over half the floor area.
Sanitary privy Every house must have a sanitary privy.
Others Proper facilities for garbage disposal, bathing and washing and a good water supply.

questions.text: A person involved in a road traffic accident has a peculiar posture as given in the image below. Which of the following is associated with this posture?
questions.solution:
The described posture is seen in decorticate rigidity caused by lesions rostral to the midbrain.

There is flexion of the upper limbs at the elbow and extension of the lower limbs. Flexion is due to rubrospinal excitation of the muscles of the upper extremities.

 

Other options:

Option A- Extensor muscle hyperactivity becomes exaggerated if the anterior lobe of the cerebellum is damaged. This is called decerebellate rigidity.

Option B- In decerebrate rigidity, the lesion involves motor tracts caudal to the midbrain. Hence, all four limbs are extended in this condition.

Option C- Uncal herniation is associated with decerebrate posturing.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G3P2 Rh-negative mother presented at 35 weeks of gestation for follow-up. Her husband is Rh-positive. She did not receive anti-D prophylaxis for her previous two pregnancies. Her current antibody titers are at 1:32. On Doppler velocimetry, the middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity is at 1.7 multiples of median (MoM). What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV) of >1.5 MoM is suggestive of fetal anemia and the next step in management is to deliver immediately since the patient is at more than 34 weeks of gestation.

The protocol for RH isoimmunisation is as follows:

Other options

Option A: Intrauterine transfusion is usually done when fetal hematocrit is <30%. It is done before 34 weeks of gestation.

Option C: It would be advisable to wait till 37-38 weeks if MCA PSV <1.5 MoM. In this case, fetal hemolysis has already occurred and immediate delivery is required.

Option D: Estimation of fetal hemolysis is done through amniocentesis or MCA PSV. Follow-up of MCA PSV every 2 weeks till 37-38 weeks is done only when MCA PSV <1.5 MoM.

questions.text: Which among the following is not true regarding congenital hypothyroidism?

choices.text: Most commonly due to dyshormonogenesis of thyroid hormone
Most common preventable cause of mental retardation
Prolongation of physiological jaundice can occur

questions.solution:
Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism, not dyshormonogenesis of thyroid hormone.

Other causes of severe fetal hypothyroidism:

  • Maternal hypothyroidism
  • Thyroid agenesis
  • Thyroid dysgenesis 
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Dyshormonogenetic goiter

It is twice as common in girls as in boys and is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation. Causes of congenital hypothyroidism can be classified based on the presence of goiter as follows:

           Goitrous (Palpable goiter)

     Non-goitrous (No palpable goiter)
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis (30%)
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Placental passage of antithyroid drugs
  • Thyroid dysgenesis (65%)
  • Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies (5%)
  • Central hypothyroidism

 Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia - early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation - usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular - slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory - macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Hematological - macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment with hematinics
  • Nervous system - hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness and somnolence, feeding difficulties

The abdomen is large, and an umbilical hernia is usually present. The temperature is subnormal, often <35°C (95°F), and the skin, particularly that of the extremities, may be cold and mottled. Edema of the genitals and extremities may be present. 

6 Ps: Pot-bellied, Pale, Puffy-faced child with Protruding umbilicus, Protuberant tongue, and Poor brain development.

questions.text: What is the effect of epinephrine on enzymes of glycogen metabolism?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine increases glycogenolysis, and thus, its effect is to phosphorylate and activate glycogen phosphorylase. 

Epinephrine and glucagon have three effects due to cAMP-mediated activation of protein kinase A as follows:

  • Phosphorylation of glycogen synthase and thus inactive it to "b" form
  • Phosphorylation of protein phosphatase 1 inhibitor and thus activate it
  • Phosphorylation of phosphorylase kinase and active it, which in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase

The rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis is catalyzed by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase.

The process of phosphorolytic cleavage of the α1 → 4 linkages of glycogen to yield single units of glucose 1-phosphate is catalyzed by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase.

Glycogen phosphorylase requires pyridoxal phosphate as the coenzyme. The phosphate group is catalytically active. There are different isoenzymes of glycogen phosphorylase in the liver, muscle, and brain.

questions.text: Which among the following is true regarding the instrument shown in the image?

choices.text: Most commonly used for rotational delivery
Used in the delivery of aftercoming head of breech

questions.solution:
The image shows Piper forceps, and it is used to assist the delivery of aftercoming head in breech presentation. It is identified by its distinct perineal curve.  

It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, and long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery.

Options A, B, and C are in reference to Kielland forceps. It has a sliding lock and thus can assist in rotational deliveries. It can correct asynclitism and is also useful in deep transverse arrest in patients with persistent occiput transverse position.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A first-year MBBS student is testing the muscle labeled X in the given cadaveric image. He remembers studying that the muscle can be easily palpated when the forearm is semi-pronated and flexed against resistance. What is the nerve supply of the given muscle?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked X is identified as the brachioradialis and it is innervated by the radial nerve.

The radial nerve is the largest branch of the brachial plexus arising from the posterior cord. Its root values are C5, 6, 7, 8, and occasionally T1. 

Brachioradialis is the most superficial muscle present on the radial side of the flexor aspect of the forearm. It forms the lateral border of the cubital fossa. 

Origin - Proximal two-thirds of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and the anterior surface of the lateral intermuscular septum.

Insertion - It ends as a flat tendon inserted on the lateral side of the distal end of the radius, proximal to the styloid process. 

Innervation - Radial nerve (C5 and C6 ) before its division above the lateral epicondyle.

Relations - The radial nerve lies in the groove between the brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus laterally and brachialis medially. The radial artery is present on its ulnar side.

Vascular supply- Radial recurrent artery. In the distal part of the muscle, it is also supplied by the radial collateral branch of the profounda brachii and radial artery.

Actions- Brachioradialis is a powerful flexor of the elbow, acting most strongly with the forearm in mid-pronation; hence, it can be tested when the semi-pronated forearm is flexed against resistance.

The image given below shows the various muscles on the flexor aspect of the forearm.

The illustration given below depicts the course and muscle innervation of radial nerve.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from the Middle East presents with intense itching, photophobia, foreign body sensation, and a thick ropy discharge from the eye. His complaints recur during every summer vacation from school. Which of the following findings is not associated with the given condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical features and recurrence during the summer season points toward vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). The finding not associated with it is Herbert pits.

Herbert pits are a corneal sign seen in trachoma.

VKC is bilateral allergic conjunctivitis that is common in children above the age of 5 years and in warm dry climates such as the Mediterranean, sub-Saharan Africa, and the Middle East.

It is IgE and cell-mediated inflammation of the conjunctiva. It results in the following findings:

Palpebral disease

  • Conjunctival hyperemia and diffuse velvety papillary hypertrophy on the superior tarsal plate
  • Macropapillae (<1 mm) have a flat-topped polygonal appearance reminiscent of cobblestones

Limbal disease

  • Horner-Trantas dots which are limbal conjunctival papillae

Keratopathy

  • Superior punctate epithelial erosions
  • Shield ulcers, which may develop when the exposed Bowman membrane becomes coated with mucus and calcium phosphate, leading to inadequate wetting and delayed re-epithelialization.
  • Pseudogerentexon resembling arcus senilus

Treatment of VKC includes allergen avoidance, antihistaminics, steroids, and immunomodulators both topical and systemic depending on the severity of the disease.

 

Clinical signs in trachoma:

Corneal signs of trachoma include:

  • Superficial keratitis
  • Herbert follicles – Limbal area
  • Pannus – superior limbus
  • Corneal ulcer
  • Herbert pits – Limbal area
  • Corneal opacity

Conjunctival signs of trachoma:

  • Congestion – On upper tarsal, fornix
  • Follicles (Containing Leber cells on histopathology) – On upper tarsal, fornix
  • Papillary hyperplasia
  • Arlt’s line – Linear scarring in sulcus subtarsalis
  • Concretions – Inspissated mucus, dead epithelial cells in the glands of Henle

questions.text: A patient presents with pain at the back of the neck. His x-ray is given below. Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
The x-ray and the clinical features identify the fracture as clay-shoveller's fracture.

Clay-shoveller’s fracture refers to the avulsion fracture of the C7 spinous process.

It occurs due to the powerful contraction of the back muscles inserted into the spinous process. The injury is painful but harmless. No treatment is usually required. Neck exercises are encouraged.

The x-ray below shows a clay-shoveller's fracture.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presented with a history of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds. There was no history of fever. The platelet count was low and the peripheral smear showed platelets, as marked by the arrows. Platelet function studies show an absence of aggregation to ristocetin but a normal response to adenosine diphosphate (ADP), epinephrine, and collagen. What is the likely diagnosis?

aPTT: Normal
Bleeding time: prolonged
Serum creatinine and urea within normal limits
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

Points that favor the diagnosis:

  • History of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds
  • Low platelet count and giant platelets
  • Prolonged bleeding time
  • Absent aggregation to ristocetin in platelet function studies 

It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to an inherited deficiency of platelet membrane glycoprotein complex Ib-IX. This glycoprotein is a receptor of the von Willebrand factor, which is needed for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. 

They mostly present with easy bruising, nose bleeds, mucosal bleeding, menorrhagia, and occasionally gastrointestinal bleeding.

Laboratory features:

  • Low platelet count
  • Large platelets on smear
  • Platelet aggregation will not occur in response to ristocetin but have normal aggregation with  ADP, collagen, or epinephrine
  • Platelet membrane glycoprotein abnormality is seen on flow cytometry.

Supportive treatment is only needed. Antiplatelet medications like aspirin should be avoided. Anti-fibrinolytic can be used in mucosal bleeding.

The below image shows giant platelets in peripheral blood smear in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

Other options:

Option A- Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive platelet disorder that results from a deficiency of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex.

Patients mainly present with petechiae, ecchymosis, excessive bleeding after dental extraction, menorrhagia, gingival bleeding, and epistaxis. 

Laboratory features:

  • Normal platelet count
  • Bleeding time- prolonged
  • Normal platelet morphology on peripheral smear
  • Platelet aggregation responses to ADP, collagen, or epinephrine are low but have normal aggregation with ristocetin
  • Flow cytometry and monoclonal antibodies confirm the diagnosis

Option B-  Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is due to the deficiency of ADAMTS13, which is the negative regulator of von Willebrand factor (vWF). They are mostly seen in adults less than 40 years of age.

They are classically manifested by a pentad of:

  • Fever
  • Neurological abnormalities
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure

Option C- von Willebrand disease is a common inherited disorder caused by deficiency or dysfunction of the vWF. Patients will have thrombocytopenia with mild to moderate mucocutaneous hemorrhage.

Laboratory features:

  • Mild thrombocytopenia
  • Slightly enlarged platelets
  • Decreased levels of von Willebrand factor
  • Low levels of ristocetin cofactor
  • Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)and bleeding time

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with progressive atrophy and weakness of his hands and forearms. On examination, he is found to have spasticity of the legs and a brisk jaw jerk.  Which of the following clinical findings would eliminate amyotrophic lateral sclerosis as a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Impaired cognitive function is not a clinical finding associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Even in the late stages of the disease, cognitive functions are preserved — remember Stephen Hawking.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a type of progressive motor neuron disease. The pathological hallmark is the destruction and death of both upper (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN). Irrespective of what is involved first, eventually ALS will involve both UMN and LMN. The motor neuron disease involving selectively the upper motor neurons is called primary lateral sclerosis, while the one involving selectively the lower motor neurons is called spinomuscular atrophy.

Patients present with insidious onset asymmetric bilateral weakness of the distal part of the lower limbs. There may be a history of cramping, particularly early in the morning. Lower motor neuron death causes muscle atrophy and fasciculations. Upper motor neuron involvement presents as exaggerated tendon reflexes and spasticity. Involvement of the corticobulbar fibers leads to exaggerated expressions of emotion, such as excessive weeping or laughing. This is called the pseudobulbar affect. Some of the patients also tend to develop frontotemporal dementia.

However, the sensory, bowel, and bladder functions and cognition is preserved even in the late stages of the disease.

questions.text: A study was conducted among the postgraduate students in a medical college to find out the time taken by them to complete various tasks in different clinical departments. Which management technique is being applied for this analysis?
questions.solution:
The management technique that is being applied for the above study is work sampling.

Work sampling is a quantitative management technique.

Work sampling refers to systematic observation and recording of the activities of one or more individuals. It is done at predetermined or random intervals. It mainly includes analyzing the type of activities performed and the time needed to perform the same.

These studies have been done on doctors, nurses, pharmacists, and laboratory technicians. This technique can find the appropriateness of the current staff, job description, and training. This may standardize the methods of performing activities and determine the manpower needed in an organization.

Management is the purposeful and effective use of resources such as manpower, materials, and finances for the fulfillment of a pre-determined objective. They consist of four basic activities: planning, organizing, communicating, and monitoring.

Management techniques are of two types:

Quantitative methods

Methods based on behavioral sciences
  • Cost-Benefit analysis
  • Cost-Effective analysis
  • Cost-Accounting
  • Input-Output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis
    • Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)
    • Critical Path Method (CPM)
  • Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making
  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Other options:

Option A: Cost-effective analysis is a management technique in which the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in terms of the results achieved. (Eg: number of lives saved or number of days free from disease).

Option C- Critical pathway method is a type of network analysis technique. The longest path in the network is called the critical path. If any delay in activity along the critical pathway, the entire study will be delayed.

Option D- Input-output analysis is an economic technique to analyze the amount of input needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities that consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time). Output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child has thin extremities and  hepatomegaly. Investigations revealed hypoglycemia, elevated uric acid levels in the blood, and marked lactic acidosis. The blood sample has the following appearance. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia (milky white plasma), hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease (type Ia). It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase.

Signs and symptoms of von Gierke disease are

  • Seizures 
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Milky white plasma - due to very high serum triglyceride levels and cholesterol levels
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Enlarged kidney
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia (blood glucose <60 mg/dL)
  • Blood uric acid levels >5 mg/dL
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by nasogastric infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch.
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Oral citrate and bicarbonate administration.
  • HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors and fibrates therapy should be started if triglyceride levels are >900 mg/dL, despite dietary therapy.
  • Allopurinol (10 mg/kg/day) should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

questions.text: Among the statements given below, all are true regarding bisphosphonates, except:

choices.text: It is used to treat Paget's disease and hypercalcemia
It is not recommended in patients with creatinine clearance <30 mL/min

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true about bisphosphonates except bisphosphonates have high bioavailability.

They are poorly absorbed from the intestine and have very low oral bioavailability, which is further reduced upon interaction with food and medication. Hence, bisphosphonates should be taken after an overnight fast, on an empty stomach, and at least 30 minutes before breakfast with a full glass of water.

Other options:

Option A: Bisphosphonates are used to treat conditions including Paget's disease, tumor-associated osteolysis, and hypercalcemia. It can also be used to treat osteoporosis, including post-menopausal and steroid-induced osteoporosis.

Option B: Bisphosphonates act by inhibiting osteoclast function, by causing its apoptosis thus preventing bone resorption.

Option D: It is excreted unchanged by the kidneys and it declines proportionally with kidney function and is hence not recommended for patients with a creatinine clearance of less than 30 mL/min.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was recently fired from work and he felt a strong urge to physically harm his boss. To try and control his urge he took up badminton to vent his anger. Identify the type of defense mechanism used by him.
questions.solution:
The defense mechanism used is sublimation.

Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism. It means to gratify an impulse by changing the end goal from a socially objectionable one to a socially valued one. Sublimation of aggressive impulses generally takes place through games or sports. Sublimation allows instincts to be channeled and not dammed up or diverted. Hence, in sublimation, feelings are acknowledged, modified, and directed toward a socially valued/acceptable goal so that modest instinctual satisfaction is achieved. In the given scenario, the man sublimates his urge to physically harm his boss (socially objectionable) by taking up badminton (socially valued).

Other options:

Option B: Altruism is a mature defense mechanism. In altruistic defense, the person gratifies an impulse by providing service or help to others even though it can be detrimental to the person itself. Example: An alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center even though he may be poor.

Option C: Displacement is a neurotic defense mechanism. In displacement, the person carries out purposeful, unconscious shifting of impulses from one object or person to another. Although the object is changed, the instinctual nature of the impulse and its aim remain unchanged and this differentiates it from sublimation where the end goal is changed to a socially acceptable one. Example: A person may be angry towards their boss for reprimanding him and wants to abuse his boss by using foul language. Here, the person displaces his anger by being rude and using foul language to his parents at home. 

Option D: Projection is an immature defense mechanism. On a nonpsychotic level, projection involves attributing one's own unacknowledged feelings to others. At higher levels, it may include misinterpreting motives, attitudes, feelings, or intentions of others.
Example: A man wishes to cheat on his wife, instead he says that he is sure his wife is cheating on him. Here, he is projecting his own unacknowledged feelings on his wife. 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: A patient was taken up for artificial pacemaker insertion. To stimulate the heart in this patient in anticipation of bradycardia, a drug was given. You note that there was a significant lowering of diastolic blood pressure, however, the systolic blood pressure remained unchanged. Also, there is sinus tachycardia. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
The drug being described here is isoproterenol.

Isoproterenol is a non-selective beta agonist with no α action. The decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is due to β2 action causing a fall in diastolic blood pressure and direct action on cardiac β1 receptors causes an increased risk of tachycardia and arrhythmias. It usually has no effect on systolic blood pressure or increases it slightly. 

Isoproterenol currently may be used as a cardiac stimulant in patients with bradycardia or heart block, particularly in anticipation of inserting an artificial cardiac pacemaker.

Adrenergic drug

Receptors it acts on

Adrenaline

α1 + α2 +β1 + β2 + weak β3 action

Noradrenaline

α1 +α2 +β1 + β3 but no β2 action

Isoprenaline

β1 + β2 + β3 but no α action

 

Below are images showing the changes in blood pressure and heart rate following the administration of Phenylephrine(α agonist), epinephrine and isoproterenol, nor epinehprine respectively.

Other options: 

Option A: Adrenaline causes increased systolic blood pressure and heart rate. It reduces the diastolic pressure when administered via slow intravenous infusion, however, it increases the diastolic blood pressure when given as a rapid intravenous injection. 

Option C: Noradrenaline causes an increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure. It causes a reduced heart rate. 

Option D: Dopamine increases systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure and either has no effect on diastolic blood pressure or increases it slightly. It can cause tachycardia however it is less prominent.

questions.text:
You received three patients in the ENT OPD. Identify which semicircular canal of the inner ear will be involved in each of these patients.

a. A patient with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo

b. A patient with nystagmus whom you will subject to caloric test

c. A patient with dehiscence in a canal which forms arcuate eminence in the base of the skull
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B-1-a, 2-b, 3-c

  • A patient with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo- Posterior semicircular canal (1) is involved.
  • A patient with nystagmus who is subjected to caloric test- Horizontal/ lateral semicircular canal (2) is stimulated.
  • A patient with dehiscence in this canal which forms arcuate eminence in the base of the skull- Superior/ anterior semicircular canal (3) is involved. 

Benign positional paroxysmal vertigo is typically thought to be caused by the dislodgement of calcium carbonate from the otoconial membrane within one of the canals. The posterior canal is most commonly affected in benign positional paroxysmal vertigo, and lateral canal pathology causes a few cases. The classical presentation of BPPV is recurrent, brief (<1 minute) episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position. Diagnosis is made by the Dix-hallpike maneuver. The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver which displaces the otolith out of the posterior canal. This ends the sensation of vertigo with positional changes relieving the symptoms. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.

Fitzgerald–Hallpike test/ bithermal caloric test procedure:

In this test, the patient lies supine with head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical, which will be stimulated here.

  • Ears are irrigated for 40 seconds alternatively with water at 30°C and at 44°C (i.e., 7° below and above normal body temperature) and eyes are observed for the appearance of nystagmus till its endpoint.
  • Time taken from the start of irrigation to the endpoint of nystagmus is recorded and charted on a calorigram.
  • If no nystagmus is elicited from any ear, the test is repeated with water at 20°C for 4 min before labeling the labyrinth dead.
  • A gap of 5 min should be allowed between two ears.

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome occurs due to the third window effect created by the thin/ dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. It is usually diagnosed in middle-aged individuals, and no racial or sexual predominance is seen. Patients present with noise or pressure-induced dizziness. Some may complain of chronic imbalance. As a result, the patient adopts avoidance of noisy environments. Also, some may have gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: It is a type of cluster C personality disorder.
It is a type of cluster A personality disorder.
It is not included in personality disorders.
It is a type of cluster B personality disorder.

questions.solution:
Obsessive-compulsive disorder is not included in personality disorders. 

Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD) is included in personality disorder cluster C.

OCPD is characterized by a pervasive pattern of preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and mental and interpersonal control, at the expense of flexibility, openness, and efficiency.

Note: OCPD and obsessive-compulsive disorder are 2 separate entities. OCPD is ego-syntonic i.e., behavior is consistent with one’s own beliefs and attitudes, unlike OCD, which is ego-dystonic and will cause distress to the patient.

questions.text: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish, pigmented lesions. Histopathology of the biopsy sample revealed pigment-laden macrophages within the lamina propria. Detailed history revealed chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The listed findings of colonoscopy and histopathology are indicative of melanosis coli, primarily caused by chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada.

Melanosis coli is characterized by lipofuscin deposition in the large intestine's lamina propria. These laxative supplements become active as they travel through the colon, inducing apoptosis and cell death in the colon's lining, which ultimately results in the dark pigmentation of the colon.

A colonoscopy is done to diagnose melanosis coli and it usually resolves after discontinuing laxative use.

Classification of laxatives:

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fibre: Bran, Psyllium/Ispaghula, Methylcellulose
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: Phenolphthalein, Bisacodyl, Sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: Senna, Cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: Prucalopride
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulphate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulphate, phosphate
    • Lactitol
    • Lactulose

Prucalopride, a stimulant laxative that acts as a 5-HT4 agonist, and osmotic laxatives like lactulose and magnesium sulfate are not associated with melanosis coli.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of weakness, weight loss, diarrhea, oily stools, and joint pain for about 6 months.  A diagnosis of malabsorption syndrome was suspected. A duodenal biopsy was done, and the findings are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea, weight loss, and chronic arthralgia and the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions points to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease.

Whipple's disease is a multi-system disease caused by infection with gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei. Clinical features include arthralgia and arthritis, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Arthralgias and arthritis are present for many years before the appearance of GI symptoms. CNS involvement is common and presents as psychiatric manifestations, memory problems, or ophthalmoplegia. Dementia may occur in later stages. Cardiac involvement may be in the form of endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis. Hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas may also be seen. Intermittent low-grade fever is present in most of the patients.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. Infiltration of lamina propria with PAS-positive macrophages containing the bacilli is diagnostic. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR, which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

The treatment regimen for Whipple's disease is ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks, followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months. Prolonged antibiotics are recommended, but there is still uncertainty prevailing regarding the optimal regimen.

Other options:

Option B: Celiac disease presents as a malabsorption syndrome due to the immune response to gluten in the diet. It is characterized by the presence of IgA antigliadin, anti-endomysial, and anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Histology will show a flat appearance of the intestine epithelium with crypt hyperplasia and villous atrophy. There is also an increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes and increased numbers of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the lamina propria. The image below shows the intestinal biopsy of a patient with celiac disease.

Option C: Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious etiology. It is predominantly seen in some tropical countries such as India. It is usually preceded by an episode of acute gastroenteritis. Small bowel biopsy resembles that of celiac disease. Treatment is with broad-spectrum antibiotics and folic acid.

Option D: Bacterial overgrowth causes deconjugation of bile acids and their deficiency in the lumen of the small intestine. This causes malabsorption, leading to diarrhea with steatorrhea.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl with a long-standing history of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis presents with a fever. Examination reveals splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show anemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated ferritin levels, and abnormal liver function tests. Bone marrow biopsy shows the findings as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of hemophagocytic lymphocytosis (HLH). This condition occurs more commonly in patients with rheumatological conditions such as systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA). The image shows shows stromal macrophages engulfing red blood cells suggestive of hemophagocytosis. 

Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) is a reactive condition that occurs in association with conditions that are characterized by signs and symptoms of systemic inflammation.

The systemic activation of macrophages and CD8+ cytotoxic T cells is a basic feature found in all kinds of HLH. The marrow's blood cell progenitors and produced components are phagocytosed by activated macrophages. Mediators secreted by lymphocytes and macrophages will inhibit hematopoiesis and also lead to systemic inflammatory symptoms. These consequences result in cytopenias and a shock-like state known as the systemic inflammatory response syndrome (also known as "cytokine storm").

Associated conditions include hematological conditions, infections, rheumatologic/immunologic conditions such as Still's disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, mixed connective tissue disorder, sarcoidosis, sJIA, Sjogren's syndrome. 

Clinical features include fever, splenomegaly, hepatitis, and encephalitis features. Other findings include respiratory abnormalities, severe hypotension, skin rashes, erythroderma, bleeding.

Laboratory findings in HLH: Anemia, thrombocytopenia, high serum ferritin, high plasma IL2 receptor levels, elevated liver enzyme levels.

Other options:

Option A: Hemolytic-uremic syndrome may have anemia and thrombocytopenia but renal function tests are not usually normal. The triad required for diagnosis is microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

Option B: Kawasaki disease may cause a fever and occurs in children, but this patient does not fulfil the diagnostic criteria for this condition. It requires the presence of fever and four of five clinical findings - conjunctivitis, mucosal changes, rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy. 

Option D: Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) usually has a temporal relationship with new drugs which is not the case in this patient. Furthermore, it usually presents with an extensive skin rash in association with visceral organ involvement, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, and atypical lymphocytosis. Although fever and abnormal liver function test results are seen in this patient, the diagnosis should be suspected when these findings are associated with a typical cutaneous eruption two to eight weeks after starting a new drug. In the pediatric population, antiepileptics and antibiotics account for the majority of cases of DRESS.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the instrument shown below.

choices.text: It is a blunt-type spinal needle.
The incidence of post-dural puncture headache is high.
It is technically more challenging to use.

questions.solution:
The image shown is the Quincke needle that is used in spinal anesthesia. Its use is associated with a high incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) due to CSF leak.

The Quincke needle is a cutting needle with an end injection.

Types of spinal needles:

Cutting needle

Non-cutting (splitting, pencil point, blunt) needle

Cut the dura

Split the dura

Hence, higher incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) due to CSF leak

Hence, lower incidence of PDPH

Technically less challenging as loss of resistance is well appreciated during lumbar puncture

Technically more challenging as loss of resistance is not well appreciated

E.g. Quincke-Babcock, Pitkin

E.g. Whitacre, Sprotte

The illustration given below shows the tips of various spinal needles.

The image given below shows a combined spinal epidural (CSE) needle.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text:
Identify the national health program from the logo given. Which age group does it cover?

RBSK-Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram

RKSK-Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram
questions.solution:

Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK):

The RBSK aims at the universal screening of the 4 ‘D’s, i.e Defects at birth, Deficiencies, Diseases, Developmental delays, including disabilities, that would lead to early identification, timely management, and ultimately a reduction in morbidity, mortality, and lifelong disability in children.

questions.text: A 13-year-old obese boy with hypothyroidism presents to you with limitations of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The x-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. Identify the true statement concerning the given radiological finding.

choices.text: Negative Trethowan sign is seen  with Klein’s line intersecting the femoral epiphysis
Positive Trethowan sign is seen  with Klein’s line not intersecting the femoral epiphysis
Negative Trethowan sign is seen with Klein’s line not intersecting the femoral epiphysis
Positive Trethowan sign is seen with Klein’s line intersecting the femoral epiphysis

questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the Positive Trethowan sign with Klein’s line not intersecting the femoral epiphysis. 

Trethowan's sign is suggestive of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis. But in SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis. This is known as positive Trethowan's sign.

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis:

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, commonly during 11-20 years, due to the weakening of the upper femoral physis.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, hyperparathyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features include limitation of abduction and internal rotation with Tenderness in Scarpa's triangle.

questions.text: Which of the following options indicates rheobase in the image below showing the strength-duration curve for muscle fiber excitation?
questions.solution:
Option B indicates rheobase in the given image showing the strength-duration curve for muscle fiber excitation.

Strength-duration curve gives an idea of the excitability of a tissue.

Strength-duration relationship arises because the same minimum electrical charge necessary to excite an action potential can come from a current that is either brief but large or prolonged but small. It is the product of strength and duration that determines excitability, and thus these two parameters are inversely related in their effectiveness.

The rheobase is the minimum intensity (strength/magnitude) of stimulation required to generate an action potential, when the stimulation is of infinite duration.

The curve below shows that at stimulus strength below point B (rheobase), the curve is flattened, indicating that it is the minimum intensity of stimulation needed to generate an action potential.

 

Utilization time is the minimum time (duration) for which the rheobase has to be applied for the excitation of tissue.

Chronaxie is the minimum time (duration) for which a stimulus double the strength of rheobase has to be applied for excitation of tissue.

Note: Chronaxie is a better index than rheobase and utilization time for comparing excitability of a tissue.

questions.text: National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study (NEXUS) criteria in a trauma patient are related to the ______ spine.
questions.solution:
NEXUS criteria are related to the cervical spine injury.

In trauma patients, without the need for radiologic imaging, the decision to discontinue the cervical c-spine collar can be made using the clinical tools namely:

  • National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study (NEXUS)
  • Canadian C-spine rule (CCR)

NEXUS criteria: There are five criteria included under NEXUS. If a trauma patient meets all five criteria, then no radiography is required and the cervical c-spine collar may be removed. However, if any one of the criteria is met then radiography is done to evaluate further.

The NEXUS criteria include:

  1. No posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness
  2. No evidence of intoxication
  3. A normal level of alertness
  4. No focal neurologic deficit
  5. No painful distracting injuries

Canadian C-spine rule: The rule is applicable to patients who are in an alert (Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15) and stable condition following trauma.

questions.text: The test below depicts the presence of which of the following defect in the left eye?
questions.solution:
The test shown is the uncover test. There is the abduction of the left eye on uncovering it (refixation movement is abduction) which suggests left esophoria. 

Uncover test: This is used to detect heterophoria (latent squint). The test is performed for both near and distant as follows.

  • The patient fixates on a distant target straight ahead.
  • The examiner covers an eye for 2-3 seconds and the cover is then removed.
  • If the covered eye had deviated, a re-fixation movement is observed on being uncovered.
  • The following are the possible results based on the re-fixation movements of the eye.
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthophoria

Adduction

(Nasal recovery)

 Exophoria
Abduction Esophoria
Downward Hyperphoria
Upward Hypophoria
  • The speed and smoothness of the recovery are noted as well as evidence of the strength of motor fusion.
  • The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Cover Test: This is used to detect heterotopia (manifest squint). Light is first shone and corneal reflections are observed. This is done to assess fixation in the deviating eye. The procedure for testing using an accommodative target and for distance is as follows.

  • The patient is asked to fixate a target straight ahead.
  • The eye in which deviation is not suspected is covered first. For example, if a right eye deviation is suspected, the left eye is covered.
  • Any movement of the right eye to take up fixation is noted.
  • The following are the possible results:
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthotopic/ Heterotopia of the covered eye
Adduction Exotropia
Abduction Esotropia
Downward movement Hypertropia
Upward movement Hypotropia

The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Classification of Strabismus 

  • Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint
    • Pseudo esotropia
    • Pseduo exotropia
  • Heterophoria—Latent squint
    • Esophoria: Convergent
    • Exophoria: Divergent
    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint
  • Concomitant
    • Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.
    • Esotropia: Convergent
      • Infantile
      • Accommodative
      • Sensory
      • Consecutive
    • Exotropia: Divergent
      • Congenital
      • Primary
      • Secondary: Sensory deprived
      • Consecutive
    • Hypertropia: Vertical squint
  • Incomitant
    • Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze
      • Paralytic squint
      • Restrictive squint
      • A and V pattern heterotropia

 

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text:
A patient with productive cough, fever, and breathlessness was found to have decreased breath sounds and a dull note on percussion on the left side. His X-ray is given below. Sputum analysis revealed a diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia. Which of the following pleural fluid characteristics would best fit the diagnosis, according to Light's criteria?

LDH- Lactate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
The pleural fluid characteristics in a patient with bacterial pneumonia would be pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH of >0.6. The pleural effusion associated with bacterial pneumonia is exudative in nature. 

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum. 

Exudative effusions occur when there is a disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage because of local factors.

Causes of exudative effusion include:

  • Bacterial pneumonia
  • Viral infections
  • Pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A child who presented with acute right iliac fossa pain and vomiting was suspected to have acute appendicitis. By looking for colicky pain and cervical lymphadenopathy, the resident is trying to rule out mesenteric lymphadenitis.

  • Endometriosis
  • Torsion/ rupture of ovarian cyst

questions.text: A patient is set to undergo surgery.  His past medical records reveal that he is homozygotic for the atypical pseudocholinesterase. Which of the following would you expect to encounter in this patient on administering succinylcholine?

choices.text: A rapid onset of action and a short duration of action
Delayed onset and a short duration of action

questions.solution:
A prolonged duration of action of succinylcholine would be expected in a patient with atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme.

Succinylcholine is rapidly metabolized by pseudocholinesterase as soon as it enters the circulation. This results in the short duration of action of succinylcholine, which is usually less than 10 minutes. 

Abnormal pseudocholinesterase, resulting from homozygous or heterozygous gene defect, cannot metabolize succinylcholine efficiently, leading to a prolonged duration of action. In patients heterozygous for the atypical pseudocholinesterase, the duration of action is prolonged modestly (2–20 minutes) whereas in homozygotes it may be prolonged up to 4–8 hours. The incidence of atypical pseudocholinesterase genes is more common in those with European ancestry.

The rapid onset of action of succinylcholine is because of its small volume of distribution resulting from very low lipid solubility. The onset is not affected by the atypical pseudocholinesterase.

questions.text: An unconscious patient is brought to the emergency room. You plan to intubate the patient using the instrument shown in the image below. What is the criticality of the instrument according to the Spaulding classification and what level of disinfection is needed for this instrument?

questions.text: 400 mg of a drug was administered to a patient, of which 40 mg is excreted in 60 minutes. Assuming the drug follows first-order kinetics, how much of the drug would remain after 2 hours?
questions.solution:
After 2 hours, 324mg of the drug will remain.

In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

In the given question, 40 mg out of 400 mg is excreted in 60 minutes ---> 40/400 = 0.1 fraction is eliminated every 60 minutes.

After 60 minutes; 400 mg - 40 mg = 360 mg remains 

The next 60 minutes (after 2 hours) = 360 * 0.1 = 36 mg is eliminated and 360 - 36 = 324 mg remains.

Simpler way -

  • 1/10 fraction is excreted in 60 minutes → 9/10 remains after 60 minutes.
  • 2 hours (120 min) is 2 times of 60 minutes.
  • So 400 * (9/10)(9/10) = 324 mg remains after 120 minutes.

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman in labor was admitted to the hospital at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, there is infraumbilical flattening of the abdomen and fetal heart sounds are heard over the flanks. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch for the progress of labor

questions.solution:
Based on the examination and auscultation findings, the fetus is in occipitoposterior position. The most appropriate management is to wait and watch for the progress of labor. 

In a majority of cases, the occiput rotates through 3/8th of the circle, and the baby is born in the occipitoanterior position. Hence, when the diagnosis of occipitoposterior position is made, labor is allowed to proceed normally when there are good uterine contractions and a favorable pelvis.

The occipitoposterior (OP) position of the fetus is when the occiput is situated posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum. It is the most common fetal malposition. It is an abnormal position seen in the vertex presentation, not an abnormal presentation. 

  • Occipitoposterior position is commonly seen in android pelvis/deflexed head.
  • The engaging diameter of this position is sub-occipitofrontal/occipitofrontal.
  • The most common type in occipitoposterior position is right OP.
  • A persistent occipitoposterior position results from a failure of internal rotation prior to birth.

Examination findings of OP position:

  • Inspection: The abdomen appears flattened below the umbilicus (infra-umbilical flattening).
  • Pelvic grips:
    • The head is not engaged.
    • The sinciput (cephalic prominence) is not prominently felt.
  • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds are heard maximally over the flanks. However, in direct OP position, they are heard in the midline.

There are three variants of OP position:

  • Left OP position (fourth position of the vertex) - When the occiput points towards the left sacroiliac joint. 
  • Right OP position (third position of the vertex) - When the occiput points towards the right sacroiliac joint. It is more common than the left OP position.
  • Direct OP position: When the occiput points directly towards the sacrum.

All three positions may be primary (present before the onset of labor) or secondary (develops after the onset of labor). 

Indications of cesarean section in occipitoposterior position:

  • Arrest of labor
  • Inadequate uterine contraction
  • Fetal distress
  • Other obstetrical indications

questions.text: A patient presents with a low-grade fever and a suppurative granulomatous skin lesion, with recent travel history to North America. Chest X-ray reveals right lung consolidation with hilar lymphadenopathy. Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar shows the following finding. What is the correct description of the slide given below?

choices.text: Yeast cells with broad-based budding in culture at 25°C
Yeast cells with broad-based budding in culture at 37°C
Yeast cells with narrow-based budding in culture at 25°C
Yeast cells with narrow-based budding in culture at 37°C

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of blastomycosis caused by Blastomycosis dermatitidis. It appears as yeast cells with broad-based budding in culture at 37°C.

The slide in the image above shows thick-walled round yeast cells with single broad-based budding depicting the figure of 8 appearance, which is suggestive of B. dermatitidis. It causes North American blastomycosis.

Blastomycosis is an infection most commonly seen in North America. It is contracted through the inhalation of contaminated soil. Primary infection usually presents as pneumonia.  Chest X-ray reveals consolidation. Disseminated disease may lead to multiple abscesses. Cutaneous lesions present as papules and nodules which progress into large ulcerative lesions.

Blastomyces is a dimorphic fungi. Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature (25°C).

Some common examples of dimorphic fungi:

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicilliosis marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Histoplasma capsulatum

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following lesions in the axilla. Histopathology of the lesions shows a dilapidated brick wall appearance. Which of the following gene is mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows red inflammatory lesions in the axilla and also the dilapidated brick wall appearance on histology is characteristically seen in Hailey-Hailey disease. It occurs due to a mutation in the ATP2C1 gene.

It is an autosomal dominant disorder occurring due to a mutation in the ATP2C1 gene encoding the SERCA calcium channel ATPase. Due to this, desmosomal function in the suprabasal and basal layers is disturbed, leading to keratinocyte separation and acantholysis.

It causes blistering, particularly in the intertriginous areas such as the axilla, inframammary, groin, etc. Since there is friction in such areas the blisters do not remain intact and can cause fissures and red inflammatory lesions.

On histology, there is a widespread loss of cohesion between suprabasal keratinocytes leading to acantholysis, which is incomplete. Hence, separated keratinocytes are still partially connected to each other giving the appearance of a dilapidated or broken brick wall.

ATP2A2 mutation is seen in Darier disease, which is characterized by dirty, warty follicles, generally on the face and limbs due to dyskeratosis (shown in the image below).

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated following a cerebrovascular accident. During the examination, it is seen that the patient's speech is fluent; he is able to understand what is said, but unable to repeat simple phrases. Naming of objects is also impaired. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is conduction aphasia.

Conduction aphasia is a form of aphasia in which both fluency and comprehension remain intact, but the patient shows an isolated impairment in their ability to repeat simple phrases and naming of objects. It occurs due to an injury in the dorsal perisylvian region, which connects Broca’s area with Wernicke’s area.

Other options: 

Option B: Wernicke's area lies in the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus. It is an important area for word and sentence comprehension. Damage to this area or blockade of the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery causes Wernicke's aphasia. It is a type of fluent aphasia in which comprehension is impaired to the spoken and written words or sentences. The speech is fluent, but contains jargon and neologisms. Therefore, the examiner cannot understand what the patient is speaking. 

Option C: Anomic aphasia is a very mild dysfunction of the language network. Comprehension and repetition are intact, but naming, word finding, and spelling are impaired. It is due to a lesion within the left hemisphere, including the middle and inferior temporal gyri. It can occur due to head trauma, metabolic encephalopathy, and Alzheimer’s disease.

Option D: In Broca's aphasia, the speech is non-fluent, with impaired repetition and naming. However, comprehension is preserved. Broca's area lies in the inferior frontal gyrus. Injury to this area or occlusion of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery leads to Broca's aphasia.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency room with pain abdomen after a road traffic accident. Further investigations showed splenic rupture. Subsequently, splenectomy was planned. Vaccination against which of the following gram-negative organisms should be administered as the prophylaxis against overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI)?
questions.solution:
All the mentioned vaccines are given to post-splenectomy patients for prophylaxis against OPSI, but gram-negative organisms out of those are only meningococcus and Haemophilus influenzae B. 

Meningococcus is a gram-negative coccus; H. influenzae is a gram-negative bacillus; and pneumococcus is a gram-positive coccus.

The CDC recommends the following vaccines for adults with asplenia:

Vaccine Recommendation

Tetanus (Td/Tdap)

 One dose every 10 years

Three doses for women ≤26 years of age or men ≤21 years of age (0, 2, 6 months)
Measles, mumps, rubella One or two doses  
Varicella Two doses (0, 4–8 weeks)  
Zoster One dose  
Influenza One dose annually  
Pneumococcal polysaccharide One or two doses

Two doses (0, 6–12 months or 0, 6–18 months)
Hepatitis B

Related Pearl: Post-Splenectomy Care

Vaccination:

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. 
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Following vaccines are given:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: 
    • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. 
    • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine:
    • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. 
    • Revaccination is needed every ten years.
  • Meningococcal vaccination:
    • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
    • Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination:
    • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Antibiotics: 

Daily prophylaxis: 

  • Penicillin and amoxicillin are preferred agents
    • For at least 1 year after surgery (at least up to the age of 5 yrs in children)
    • For immunocompromised, at least up to the age of 18 yrs

Early empirical:

  • Early empirical treatment to be initiated in presence of systemic symptoms of infection e.g - chills, rigor, fever, vomiting, etc.
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is the preferred choice for most adults and children
  • If allergic to beta-lactam, use levofloxacin/moxifloxacin.

Antithrombotics:

  • Low dose heparin for at least 4 weeks helps in perioperative thromboembolism prevention
  • In presence of extreme reactive thrombocytosis (>10,00,000/mm3) low dose aspirin can also be given.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, her height is normal and the breast development is appropriate for her age. However, the axillary and pubic hair is sparse. On ultrasound, an absent uterus is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has primary amenorrhea, and the most likely diagnosis is androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder, in which there is a decrease in the function of the androgen receptor. They appear as phenotypically normal females at birth and often present with primary amenorrhea at puberty. External genitalia will appear normal with scant or absent pubic and axillary hair, shortened vagina. The uterus and fallopian tubes are absent. However, they develop breasts during pubertal maturation due to abundant androgen-to-estrogen conversion. Testes may be palpable in the labia or inguinal area or in the abdomen.

There are two causes of primary amenorrhea with the absent uterus and the differences between them are as follows:

Other options:

Option B: Mullerian agenesis would have normal pubic and axillary hair but absent or rudimentary uterus.

Option C: Turner's syndrome is associated with the presence of a uterus, short stature and raised FSH levels.

Option D: Amenorrhea due to hypothalamic failure may be due to eating disorders, excessive exercise, or stress. It can also be inherited like 

Kallmann syndrome. The uterus is normal with decreased FSH and LH levels.
