questions.text: In pernicious anemia, which process is defective?

choices.text: Uptake of vitamin B12 by ileal mucosa
Activation of vitamin B12 in gastric juice
Transport of vitamin B12 in blood
Action of vitamin B12 at cellular level

questions.solution:
Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies that impair the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF). This is required for the uptake of vitamin B12 by the ileal mucosa. 

There are three types of autoantibodies in pernicious anemia namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of the intrinsic factor.

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the local police station with a complaint of sexual assault by an unknown man. The accused was caught by the police later. Which of the following examination findings in the victim and accused suggest that the assault has occurred within the last 10 hours?
Examination finding Sperms in the vagina of victim Smegma on corona glandis of accused
A Motile  Absent
B Nonmotile  Present
C Motile  Present
D Nonmotile   Absent
questions.solution:
The Correct answer is option A.

Mobile sperms in the vagina can be usually detected up to 6–12 hours after intercourse. Once deposited, sperms may be recovered up to 72 hours from the vagina, but they lose their motility. Spermatozoa can be detected on the body up to 72 hours after an assault, while semen can be detected for up to 96 hours after an assault. 

The absence of smegma on the corona glandis of the accused suggests that he has had sexual intercourse in the last 24 hours. 

This evidence is useful in estimating the time of the assault. Presence of venereal diseases and wounds can also be assessed to estimate time of assault. The absence of spermatozoa in the female genital tract does not rule out the possibility of a sexual assault.

questions.text: An autopsy of a patient who died due to heart failure secondary to mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy was conducted. The histopathological specimen of the cardiac tissue showed the finding shown below.  The specific cells called 'Anitschkow' cells form an important part of this structure. What are these cells made of?
questions.solution:
The lesion shown in the histopathological slide is Aschoff's body and the most probable diagnosis is rheumatic heart disease (RHD). The Anitschkow cells are activated macrophages. 

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis. During acute rheumatic fever, Aschoff bodies may be found in any of the three layers of the heart that results in pericarditis, myocarditis, or endocarditis. 

Chronic inflammation leads to diffuse thickening and fibrosis of the valve leaflets, often with calcific deposits. Fibrinoid necrosis occurs due to inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations called verrucae develop along the lines of closure. Irregular thickenings present in the subendocardium are called MacCallum plaques.

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve leaflet is thickened, with commissural fusion and shortening. There is thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. This can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice, leading to a fish mouth appearance (button hole).

Some major manifestations of rheumatic Fever are:

  • Migratory polyarthritis of the large joints 
  • Pancarditis (myocarditis, pericarditis, or endocarditis)
  • Subcutaneous nodules (typically on extensor surfaces of extremities)
  • Erythema marginatum, an irregular circinate skin rash 
  • Sydenham chorea, a neurologic disorder with involuntary rapid movements

questions.text: A female patient presents with a loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. She gives a history of being treated for herpes infection in the past. After a detailed examination, she is suspected of having cranial nerve palsy. Involvement of which component of the cranial nerve nucleus led to her presenting feature?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of facial nerve palsy. The component of the cranial nerve nucleus that was affected and that led to her presenting feature is the special visceral afferent.

Components of facial nerve nuclei in the brainstem:

  • General somatic afferent - Sensation from part of the tympanic membrane, external acoustic meatus, and skin behind the pinna. Proprioception from facial muscles.
  • Special visceral afferent - Taste from anterior 2/3rds of the tongue.
  • General visceral efferent - Parasympathetic to lacrimal gland and mucosa of nasal and oral cavities; sublingual and submandibular salivary glands.
  • Special visceral efferent - Motor to muscles of facial expression, stapedius, posterior belly of digastric, and stylohyoid

questions.text: During your community medicine postings, each student is assigned a family in the neighboring district for evaluating various social, economic, and health parameters. You were asked to grade the families according to the modified Kuppuswamy’s socioeconomic status scale. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this scale?

choices.text: Kuppuswamy scale does not include housing
This scale can be used for both rural and urban areas
There are 5 socio-economic classes according to this scale
Monthly income of the family is taken into consideration in this scale

questions.solution:
The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas and not in rural areas. 

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family 
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family 

Each of the components is assigned a score. It is then classified into socio-economic classes based on the total score as follows:

Socio-economic class Total Score
I Upper 26-29
II Upper-middle 16-25
III Lower-middle 11-15
IV Upper-lower 05-10
V Lower <5

Note:

  • Uday Pareek scale should be used for those in rural areas. 
  • BG Prasad scale can be used in both urban and rural areas.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Knudson's two-hit hypothesis theory on retinoblastoma?

choices.text: Familial type is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait
It states mutations of both alleles of RB at chromosome locus 13q14 are required to produce retinoblastoma
In sporadic cases, both normal RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast
In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the RB gene and the other copy is normal

questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.

Knudson's hypothesis, also known as the two-hit hypothesis or multiple-hit hypothesis, states that cancer is the result of accumulated mutations in a cell's DNA. Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB at chromosome locus 13q14, are required to produce retinoblastoma.

In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the RB gene in the germline (the first hit), and the other copy is normal. Retinoblastoma develops when the normal RB allele is mutated in retinoblasts as a result of a spontaneous somatic mutation (the second hit). Most individuals inheriting a germline defect in one RB allele develop unilateral or bilateral retinoblastoma as it is an autosomal dominant disease.

Sporadic cases are comparatively rare. In sporadic cases, both normal RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits).

questions.text:
According to WHO, which of the following indicators is used to calculate both HDI and PQLI?

HDI - Human Development Index
PQLI - Physical Quality of Life Index
questions.solution:
Literacy is used in the measurement of both HDI and PQLI.

The components of the Human Development Index (HDI) include life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.

Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development:

  • A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth
  • Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and
  • A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.

Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate are components of the Physical quality of life index (PQLI).

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with complaints of right-sided facial weakness, tinnitus, dysphagia for 2 weeks, and progressive hearing loss for 2 years. A glomus tumor was suspected in this patient. Which of the following investigations will not be done for the above situation?
questions.solution:
In a clinical suspicion of a glomus tumor, a biopsy for histopathology is contraindicated.

Glomus tumor is an extremely vascular benign tumor. A preoperative biopsy is never done in glomus tumors as they bleed profusely, and there is an increased risk of injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear. It originates from the glomus bodies and consists of paraganglionic cells from the neural crest. It is a nonencapsulated tumor and a locally invasive tumor. 

Glomus tumor is most often seen in women in the fourth to fifth decade of life.

A patient typically presents with progressive conductive hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus, dizziness, and facial paralysis. If the tumor presents as a polyp, a history of spontaneous bleeding from the ear is seen. 

Otoscopy examination shows a red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane as a "rising sun" appearance since the tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear as shown below:

Dysphagia and hoarseness of voice are present as late features due to IXth- XIIth cranial nerve paralysis.

Glomus tumors are of two types, glomus jugulare, which arises from the dome of the jugular bulb, and glomus tympanicum, which arises from the promontory of the middle ear. 

Glomus tumors are classified based on Fisch classification:

Class Extent 
Class A Tumor limited to the middle ear (mesotympanum)
Class B

Tumor limited to the middle ear (meso- and hypotympanum) and the mastoid
Class C

Tumor involving the infralabyrinthine compartment of the temporal bone and extending to the petrous apex
Class D

Intracranial extension. It can be intradural or extradural

Glomus tumors are paragangliomas, secreting catecholamines. This is diagnosed by testing the patient's 24-hour urine collection for urinary VMA (vanillylmandelic acid) or metanephrines. 

CT scan helps to distinguish the glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare and also to differentiate it from the aberrant carotid artery. MRI shows the soft tissue extends.

Four-vessel angiography shows the involvement of the jugular bulb, carotid artery, and intradural extension. It also helps to identify multiple glomus tumors and to find the feeding vessel of the tumor.

It can be removed surgically. Radiation and embolization can be used to reduce vascularity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with painless bleeding during defecation was found to have internal hemorrhoids on proctoscopy. Shown below is a method of surgical treatment for this patient. What are the possible grade(s) of the patient's condition for which this surgery can be performed?
questions.solution:
The image shows open hemorrhoidectomy, which is indicated for an internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids and grade 2 hemorrhoids not cured by non-operative treatments. 

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, and smooth muscle fibers located in the anal canal. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:

  • Internal Hemorrhoids 
  • External Hemorrhoids

External hemorrhoids are distal to the dentate line and are covered with anoderm; these may engorge, causing pain. Thrombosis of these external hemorrhoids causes severe pain. Internal hemorrhoids are characterized by bright red, painless bleeding, or prolapse.

Internal hemorrhoids are stratified into four grades as follows:

GRADE

SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS

First degree

Bleeding; no prolapse

Second degree

Prolapse with spontaneous reduction

Third degree

Prolapse requiring manual reduction

Fourth degree

Prolapsed, cannot be reduced

Management of external hemorrhoids: 

External hemorrhoids do not require treatment unless they become thrombosed. Acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoids cause intense pain and perianal mass during the first 24 to 72 hours. Patients who present within 72 hours of thrombosis are treated with elliptical excision performed under local anesthesia.

If the patient presents to the hospital after 72 hours of thrombosis, then it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed. 

Management of internal hemorrhoids:

Bleeding from grade 1 and grade 2 hemorrhoids often improve with the addition of dietary fiber, use of stool softeners, increase in fluid intake, and avoidance of straining.

Grade 1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.

Rubber band ligation involves pulling the mucosa 1 to 2 cm proximal to the dentate line into a rubber band applier. The rubber band strangulates the underlying tissue, causing scarring and sloping off the mass in a few days. 

Sclerotherapy involves injecting 1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) into the submucosa of internal hemorrhoids.

Indications for surgery: 

  1. Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids/grade 2 hemorrhoids not cured by non-operative treatments 
  2. Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
  3. Early-grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures

Surgical procedures used in the removal of internal hemorrhoids:

1) Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation

2) Open hemorrhoidectomy: Artery forceps are applied to the skin-covered external components of the hemorrhoid, and traction is used to visualize the internal components. Dissection of the lateral pedicle is performed and, finally, the pedicles are transfixed. Mucocutaneous bridges are left intact in this technique. The image below shows the procedure. 

3) Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy: The hemorrhoids are excised with the overlying mucosa. The hemorrhoids are dissected from the underlying sphincter and the mucosal defect is then closed. The image below shows the procedure.

4) Stapled hemorrhoidopexy (Longo operation) - The hemorrhoids are pulled up, and a purse-string suture is placed a few centimeters above the dentate line. Then, a circumferential rectal mucosectomy is performed using a circular stapler. This technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence; however, it is quick to perform, less painful, and less traumatic. The image below shows stapled hemorrhoidopexy.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty breathing. Chest X-ray shows multiple linear opacities in both lower lungs. Investigations reveal diffuse interstitial fibrosis. Which of the following will be seen in this patient's pulmonary function tests?

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for carbon monoxide
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in the ship repair industry with linear opacities on chest X-ray and diffuse interstitial fibrosis is asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern; hence, decreased DLCO will be seen.

Asbestosis results in diffuse interstitial fibrosis leading to restrictive lung disease. Findings of pulmonary function testing:

  • Decreased total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity (VC), and residual volume (RV) due to diffuse fibrosis
  • In restrictive diseases, both FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in the first second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) are reduced but FEV1/FVC ratio is normal or even increased as FVC is reduced to a greater degree due to decreased compliance.
  • An FEV1/FVC ratio > 0.7 signifies restrictive lung disorder, whereas <0.7 is seen in obstructive diseases.
  • Damage to the pulmonary capillaries due to fibrosis causes a decrease in diffusing capacity, resulting in reduced DLCO.
  • Flow volume loop in restrictive diseases shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

questions.text: Which of the following is a second-generation antihistamine?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine.

H1 antagonists are divided into first-generation and second-generation drugs. First-generation antihistamines have a strong sedative property and also block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Carbinoxamine
  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine
  • Chlorpheniramine
  • Cyproheptadine
  • Cinnarizine

Second-generation antihistamine- They are less sedative because of less central nervous system penetration and do not block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Fexofenadine
  • Loratadine
  • Desloratadine
  • Cetirizine, Levocetirizine

Important uses of H1 receptor blockers:

  • Allergic rhinitis and urticaria- They block histamine-mediated actions
  • Antinausea and antiemetics- scopolamine and dimenhydrinate are be used in the treatment of motion sickness. Doxylamine is used in the treatment of vomiting in pregnancy.
  • Antiparkinsonism- Diphenhydramine can be used to suppress extrapyramidal symptoms caused due to antipsychotic medications
  • Local anesthesia- Diphenhydramine and promethazine block sodium channels and can act as local anesthetics.

Adverse effects

  • Sedation
  • Antimuscarinic action
  • Orthostatic hypotension due to alpha receptor blockade

questions.text: The histopathological appearance of the renal arteriole of a patient with a BP of 230/120 mm Hg is as below. The fundoscopy showed bilateral retinal flame hemorrhages. The pathophysiology of her hypertension is likely due to:

choices.text: Hyaline deposition in the small capillaries
Basophilic calcification of the muscular arteries
Fatty  streaks and foamy macrophages in tunica intima

questions.solution:
The given scenario of severe hypertension (blood pressure ≥180/≥120 mmHg) with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages and/or papilloedema) is suggestive of malignant hypertension (also known as hypertensive emergency/crisis). The histopathological image shows fibromuscular hyperplasia of the arterioles having a typical onion-skin appearance. This is seen in hyperplastic arteriosclerosis. 

Malignant hypertension is characterized by severe hypertension with ischemic complications of multi-organs. The commonly affected organs are eye (resulting in retinal hemorrages, hard exudates, cotton wool spots with or without papilledema) and kidney (causing malignant nephrosclerosis). 

The pathophysiology behind this condition is due to hyperplastic arteriosclerosis. It affects small arteries and arterioles causing thickening and hardening of the wall with loss of elasticity. 

Histopathological features of malignant hypertension are - 

  • Smooth muscle and collagen proliferation are seen resulting in reduced size of the lumen. This further leads to concentric, laminated arteriolar thickening of the vessel wall with duplication of the basement membrane giving rise to an onion-skin appearance. 
  • They are also accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arterioles), particularly in the kidney and can lead to acute renal failure. 
  • Small, pinpoint petechial hemorrhages may appear on the cortical surface from rupture of arterioles or glomerular capillaries, giving the kidney a peculiar flea-bitten appearance.
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, DIC, and encephalopathy may also be present. The prognosis is very poor if left untreated.
  • No changes are seen in the heart. 
 

Other options - 

Option A: Hyaline deposition in the vessel wall leads to benign hypertension. Here, the arteriolar wall is thickened with increased protein deposition (hyalinized), and the lumen is irregular and markedly narrowed. It can also cause bilaterally contracted kidneys with the renal surface showing diffuse, fine granularity that resembles grain leather. 

Option C: Basophilic dystrophic calcification in tunica media and internal elastic lamina is seen in Monckeberg's medial sclerosis. The vessels are hardened and can be felt like bone on palpation. They are usually asymptomatic and are seen in age groups more than 80 years. Lumen size is normal here. 

Option D: Fatty streaks and foamy macrophages in tunica intima are characteristic of atherosclerosis. 

The cells marked in the image below are the foam cells in atheromatous plaques. They refer to lipid-laden monocytes/ macrophages or smooth muscle cells within the plaques.
